PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of courtesy, I wish to advise the House that the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) will not be present in the House today and tomorrow. He is absent on Government business. In his absence the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) will handle any questions relating to his portfolio.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I remind the honourable gentleman of the promise he made that, under the Medicare scheme introduced by his Government, all Australians would have improved access to quality health care at a lower cost. Given that public hospital waiting queues have trebled since the introduction of Medicare, that 10 per cent of nurses in the public hospital system resigned in the first 12 months of the operation of Medicare and that under Medicare there has been the highest level of industrial disputation within the hospital system ever seen in this country, including the first walkout of doctors in Australian history, how can he now say with any degree of honesty or accuracy that Australians are better off now with regard to health care than they were when the coalition Government was last in office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government takes very considerable pride in its achievements in the health field. I am rather surprised to hear the comments by the Leader of the Opposition about the walkout by doctors. Of course, what we witnessed during the period in question was the unbelievable sight and hypocrisy of the present Opposition which spent all of its time attacking every other union in the country which considered or contemplated taking any form of direct action to improve their working conditions. But when it came to the position of arguably the most powerful and avaricious union in the country-the Australian Medical Association-of course its tune changed. The doctors were given every aid, comfort and support by this Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members opposite have no morality and no principle when it comes to the question of direct action and walkouts. They encouraged the doctors to walk out and take direct action on these matters. As far as this Government is concerned, we will be quite happy when we go to the next election to stand on our record in this area and compare it with the pathetic performance of the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Special Minister of State been drawn to an editorial in Saturday's Age criticising the Commonwealth Government for the resources provided to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence? Can the Minister inform the House of the Government's actions in relation to the funding of the ABCI?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The Age apparently had been told some time in the last week or so that there was a dispute between the Commonwealth and the States concerning the funding of the ABCI. Bob Bottom wrote an article to this effect on Wednesday last. No consultation or inquiries were made of me, my office or my Department about any of the matters contained in his article. The Age referred to my rebuttal of the article on Thursday but it repeated its original assertions in an editorial on Saturday. The ABCI is ultimately responsible to the Australian Police Ministers Council. I would like to emphasise that there is no dispute between Commonwealth and State Ministers on the ABCI.

ANSWER.PARA: It appears that some discussions between Commonwealth and State police and officials have resulted in a detailed briefing on some bureaucratic wrangles being given to the Age and, even more surprisingly, printed by it. The errors in the original article, and repeated in the editorial, are legion. The Bureau's budget was not cut by 28.5 per cent in 1984, nor was its staff component reduced by five. The Age's source apparently does not distinguish between budgets allocated and the original bids by agencies. The Commonwealth did not propose to renegotiate the agreement with the States to change the basis for the sharing of costs of non-police staff as asserted by the Age's informant. No proposal has been put forward by the Commonwealth to Ministers to place the ABCI under a Federal statutory authority.

The facts are that the ABCI has been well supported by the Commonwealth. Funding has been increased over the past four years and the growth of staff provided by the Commonwealth has more than kept pace with the staff provided by State police. The funding in 1983-84 from the Commonwealth was $1.2m; in 1984-85 it was $1.4m; in 1985-86 it was $2.6m; in 1986-87 it was $2.2m and, in the last two years including the commitment of the drug summit, it was $1.5m. Present staffing of the ABCI is 44, of which 22 are provided by the Commonwealth. It is certainly true that the ABCI estimates have been subject to the same scrutiny as the estimates of all other agencies and it has not always received everything it has asked for. The Commonwealth makes no apology for expecting the ABCI to justify its estimates. At the drug summit the Commonwealth commitment of $1.5m to enhance the automatic data processing capacity of the ABCI was announced. Ministers have now been informed that implementation of the Bureau's drug data base project may require a great deal more. Honourable members would no doubt agree that a project now estimated to cost at least $4m and a further $1m per year requires examination. This revised proposal has been considered by a meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers, who agreed that options for implementing this proposal, including cost sharing proposed by the Victorian Minister, should be considered by the full meeting of the Police Ministers Council in December. This hardly seems to warrant the description of a Federal-State wrangle casting doubt on the future of the ABCI.

Finally, the Age's sources seem to think that it is not proper for Australia to assist in funding a computer project for the Thai narcotics control board when they have not been given all they have wished for here in Australia. This is very much a Fortress Australia mentality. Presumably they are aware of the origin of much of the heroin entering Australia and the vital importance of overseas intelligence and co-operation in combating drug trafficking. But it seems to the Age that when there is a bureaucratic fight common sense goes out the window. I just make this offering, in conclusion, to the Age journalists in Melbourne or to anybody else: If they require a briefing on the ABCI I will be only too pleased to arrange it for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his general description of anybody who criticises the fringe benefits tax as greedy, as a rorter and as a friend of tax dodgers. Does the Prime Minister believe that this description accurately applies to members of the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association? Does he believe this description applies to many non-profit organisations, such as the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the National Trust? Does he now believe that it applies to his colleague, Senator Richardson, in the light of Senator Richardson's Singleton speech? Or does the Prime Minister now agree that the extravagant rhetoric that he has used to smear honest Australians who genuinely oppose the fringe benefits tax has been without justification or warrant?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member asks with whom I am in agreement on the fringe benefits tax. I find myself in total agreement with the Federal President of the honourable member's Party, Mr Valder. I cannot find anyone in this country who has more explicity put the case for the fringe benefits tax than the Federal President of the Liberal Party. I know that the feelings I have for him are not always shared by the honourable member for Kooyong, but I cannot help that. The Federal President of the Liberal Party rightly said that what had happened in this country with regard to fringe benefits was a disease and he congratulated this Labor Government or its courage in tackling the disease of fringe benefits. That is who I agree with; the Federal President of the Liberal Party.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of the Commonwealth Bank employees, I make this general point: The Commonwealth Bank employees are objecting to the Commonwealth Bank, which has happily received a benefit of a flaw in the taxation system, now seeking to go back on its traditional arrangements with staff because that flaw has been removed. That is not an objection to a fair tax system; that is an objection to an employer which was happy to meet its obligations to its employees on the basis of a tax advantage but is not prepared to meet its obligations as soon as, in the interests of fairness, that advantage is taken away. That is something that will have to be resolved between the Commonwealth Bank and its employees, but that is not to be seen as an objection to what is unquestionably a significant improvement to fairness and equity in the taxation system in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Trade advise the House of the outcome of the deliberations of the Australian Coal Consultative Council last week particularly with regard to the new regime for coal export controls?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and particularly for the work that he and his committee have been doing in consulting the industry in relation to this matter. At the time the Prime Minister announced the streamlined arrangements for export controls on coal in the liberalisation of that regime, it was made clear that we intended to consult widely with the industry, both the producers and the unions, and the State governments to ensure that the Government was able to exercise its proper responsibilities in terms of safeguarding the national interest as far as coal exports were concerned. The committee which the honourable member chaired did valuable work in that regard.

ANSWER.PARA: Last week the Australian Coal Consultative Council, which represents all sections of the industry, met to consider this matter and agreed on a number of important questions which the Government had put to it in relation to the continuing involvement of the Government in export controls on coal. The ACCC recognised that the decision of the Government was not made or designed to permit Australian companies to take existing market shares from one another but rather to increase Australia's total share of the world coal market. The Coal Consultative Council went on to note the sort of criteria, not necessarily exhaustive, which the Government would entertain when considering using its reserve power in relation to the price of coal being exported from Australia. Since the new regime of export controls there have been some 70 settlements involving some 10 million tonnes of coal and all but two of those settlements went without a hitch. There were two, however, on which I considered it necessary to withhold approval because I considered in both cases that the prices being asked for in those settlements were below the prices that would be normally justified by the world market price. As a result of withholding that approval, the companies came back to us within 24 hours with an increased price of some $3 a tonne. So I think that indicates the importance of retaining some reserve power and stands in stark contrast to what the Opposition is holding out as its policy of total disinterest about the way in which our No. 1 export is sold to the world.

It is folly for the coal mining unions to be entertaining industrial action at the moment in protest at this decision by the Government. The Government is trying to give the coal producers the maximum flexibility consistent with the national interest to not only hold on to their existing markets in the face of weakening prices, but also to gather new markets both within our traditional areas of interest and in other parts of the world. People who suggest that we could, by some magical means through the creation of a national coal marketing authority, hold the position against the tide of lowering prices of coal are confusing themselves. The Australian Financial Review this morning made the very important point that in relation to wheat, where we have almost total acquisition by a central marketing board selling our wheat to the world, that board is not able to resist the lower prices we are being forced to accept for our wheat. The same sort of thing is the case in relation to coal. The coal industry, which is, as I say, our No. 1 export industry, faces very difficult circumstances. Those circumstances are not made any easier by the kind of disruption which has been threatened in some quarters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism in his capacity as Chairman of the Ministerial Committee on Government Information and Advertising. I refer the Minister to the Government's taxpayer funded $2m advertising campaign which suggests that the fringe benefits tax will relieve the tax burden on lower income groups. In view of Senator Richardson's admission that the fringe benefits tax will hit hard at many family breadwinners on low to medium incomes, what action will the Government take to correct the misleading nature of its tax advertisements?
—None.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the economic prospects facing Australia over the next 12 months?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dobell for his penetrating question. If honourable members cast their minds back to the Budget Speech delivered by my colleague the Treasurer they will recall that he made it clear that there was an expectation that economic conditions would improve in this country in the first half of 1987. I am very pleased to say that the most recent economic indicators are consistent with the expectation then expressed. I refer, amongst other things, to the greater confidence in the Australian dollar, to the indicated improvement in consumer confidence and also to the increasing evidence that domestic manufacturers are recognising the opportunities offered to them by the significant depreciation that has occurred in this country. These indications and this evidence are the direct result of the Government's economic policies that have been put in place to cope with the slump in the prices of our major exports. It is little wonder in these circumstances that the Government has been praised by the future shadow Treasurer of the Opposition, Mr John Hewson. The future shadow Treasurer, Mr Hewson, writing in the Business Review Weekly of 6 November, had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . credit must go to the Government for some of the initiatives it has taken so far and the direction in which it has moved. Its early moves to continue the process of deregulating the financial system, to begin asset tests on some government benefits, to begin to rein in government expenditure, to begin the process of tax reform, to be prepared to renegotiate wage fixation principles and work practices have been moves in the right direction.

I guess it is little wonder that the future shadow Treasurer of the Opposition should be saying things like that because no doubt he is experiencing a great deal of frustration witnessing the policyless position which characterises this Opposition, a concern, obviously, which has moved the honourable member for Denison to make the comments he has made recently. Honourable members will recall that on the World Today program on 3 November the honourable member for Denison had this to say about the Opposition, of which he is a member:
I think it's a question of taking stock and deciding where we're going and what sort of policies we're going to have.
That is all future tense. Honourable members opposite have been there for 3 1/2 years and have not yet got any policies. That led the honourable member for Denison to go on:
I don't think we can go on with this business of saying we won't tell you our policies now, you'll have to wait till later.
It is good to see the honourable member for Denison expressing his total contempt for the leadership of the Opposition. In the same interview the honourable member said:
I think we have to watch our performance and that is all of our performances from the leadership right down.

I had cause to say after the previous exercise by the Opposition: `You were threadbare at Thredbo'. Is it threadbare again. Again, those opposite have no policies, which is not surprising when, out of a potential of 73 Liberal members, the best they could do was summon up 46. I suppose that they thought it was not worth going because the conference would be a continuation of the same irrelevant policyless performance which has characterised this pathetic Opposition for 3 1/2 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his comments on 6WF in Perth last Thursday concerning his preparedness to change the fringe benefits tax if unforeseen issues arise. I also refer the Treasurer to his comments yesterday that at this point no areas of the fringe benefits tax require further adjustment. Given that Senator Richardson has stated that changes need to be made to the fringe benefits tax and the continuing uncertainty in the community over the fringe benefits tax, will the Treasurer explain exactly where the Government stands on changes to the fringe benefits tax and whether there will be any additional significant changes to the fringe benefits tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Getting the honourable member for Mackellar to ask where the Government stands on tax would make a cat laugh. This Opposition has been trotting around, dodging questions and ducking punches on radio stations for weeks about fringe benefits taxation. Still it will not come clean. Let me give a morsel of the performance of the Leader of the Opposition-that great person of principle, Honest John-on the John Laws program. Laws asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Would you agree that within certain bounds that anybody who accepts a benefit in lieu of payment, let us say if they were earning in excess of $60,000, they accept other benefits in lieu of payment, so they can avoid paying tax on it, that they should fall at the hands of the FBT?
This is the answer:
If the purpose of the arrangement is to avoid tax then it ought to be stopped. It ought to be taxed and it ought to be clobbered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—That was said by J. Howard, who went on:

ANSWER.PARA: I have said all along that if the purpose of the arrangement is to avoid tax then it should be stopped.
He goes on-and this is where the dodginess comes in:
. . . many of the arrangements . . . would in fact be caught by the existing anti-avoidance provisions of the taxation law that I put into the law in 1981.

That is Part IVa. We keep getting this shonky answer about Part IVa, the catch-all avoidance provision which, the Commissioner of Taxation has made clear, can operate only if there is a head of power within the tax Act to make an assessment under. To use Part IVa the Commissioner would have to fall back on section 26 (e) which he, the Commissioner, has said will not work. The Leader of the Opposition knows that Part IVa only gives the Commissioner a right to raise an asessment. There has to be a head of power within the tax Act to raise the assessment. The only head of power within the tax Act is 26 (e), which cannot be used. This is an example of the crazy points that the Opposition has been putting across on one radio program and one television interview after another because it will not come clean on the fact that it does not have a policy in relation to fringe benefits taxation. The Leader of the Opposition went on to say:
The Tax Office really does not want to know about that section of the FBT arrangements. It is a catch all section for general anti-avoidance provisions, but then needs a head of power under 26 (e)-
the thing the Opposition favours-
I suspect that these sorts of things are caught but the point is simply this: If the purpose is to avoid tax, it ought to be stopped.

One would think from that that that is a position of principle from the Opposition, that it is opposed to fringe benefits taxation; but what do we find? It is all about Part IVa which cannot be used without relying on section 26 (e). Then we have the honourable member for Mackellar who has asked me this question. In Rydges magazine of October this year the honourable member for Mackellar was asked:
You surely do not intend to go back to open slather and allow such things as hostess allowances and private scholarships?
The honourable member for Mackellar answered:
No. The situation is that we have much tightened up on what applied pre-FBT but using the old provision of the Act.
That is section 26 (e). Then we have the Leader of the National Party, who said in Bathurst on 6 November:
Indeed, the old section 26 (e), which is part of the existing tax system, has been used by the Tax Commissioner in the past. There is no reason why it could not have been used.

In other words, he was saying that there is no reason why it cannot be used in the future. The National Party has referred to section 26 (e), the shadow Treasurer has referred to section 26 (e) and the Leader of the Opposition has referred to Part IVa relying on 26 (e), which the three of them know cannot be used, and then they say that they want us to stand up and say where we stand on fringe benefits. What a sick, squalid joke on the part of a major political party when, facing a question like the non taxation of benefits, it does not have an intellectual and honest position in relation to this question. Is it any wonder that Mr Hewson, who is going to be much quoted today, in relation to tax reform said:

This process certainly has not been helped by the Opposition stating that it will abolish the fringe benefits tax without being prepared to say what it will do. Having begun to declare its tax policies, the Opposition's credibility on tax will continue to be questioned until it specifies all the detail.
That is his position. The Prime Minister referred earlier to what the honourable member for Denison has said, and I will quote it again:

I don't think we can go on with this business of saying we won't tell you our policies . . . The public of Queensland were very happy that we agreed to repeal the FBT but not happy that we wouldn't tell them what the alternative tax policy was going to be.

That is the position of the Australian Opposition in relation to fringe benefits taxation. The Opposition should not ask me about the fringe benefits tax and where the Government stands on it. Where the Government stands has been very clear. Let me make this quite clear, as I have said, that we can see no cause for other changes but if we were to see cause we would make changes, like we did to every other section of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Is it a fact that a prominent Black Muslim person recently visited Australia under immigration guidelines which have applied for some time? Will the Minister outline these guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a separate set of guidelines for temporary visitors to this country who are visiting for a short time and for those who are applying to become permanent settlers. I can show just how long the guidelines have applied by giving one prominent example to the honourable member for Scullin. In 1982 when guess who were governing-the parties, of course, of those represented opposite-one Vanessa Redgrave, a member of the British Trotskyist Workers Revolutionary Party, visited this country openly under the previous Government's administration.
—She came and saw me.

—She not only personally asked to see the now Minister for Foreign Affairs but also, I am sure, saw a lot of other people while she was here. In fact, she actually openly campaigned for the Palestine Liberation Organisation while she was here. She was very offensive in a lot of things she said while she was here. She claimed that the Israeli nation was racist. She claimed that zionists collaborated with nazis. She stated that the film proceeds of the film she was then showing would go to making another film linking zionism with nazism. That outrageous lady came into Australia under the policy guidelines that were in place under the Government of those who now sit opposite. We did not attack that then, for very good reasons; because we knew that the more that she ranted and raved against certain people the more those certain people would get support and she would lose support. But I also supported that at that time, and continue to support it, because we know that this country, as a liberal democracy, should be treating its people as adults and allowing freedom of speech and the exchange and free flow of ideas.

ANSWER.PARA: We did not attack the then Government on the letting in of Vanessa Redgrave because we believe that we do not have to protect our people from such ratbags as Vanessa Redgrave or anybody else visiting this country unless they are advocating violence, have a history of violence or represent terrorist organisations such as the Palestine Liberation Organisation. With those principles in mind, when this Mr Lawrence J. Prescott, who calls himself Abdul Akhbar Muhammad, was allowed to visit us he did so quite within the policy guidelines that have applied for some time. He belonged of course to some Black Muslim group but he had no history of violence whatsoever. He was not linked to an organisation which is known to be a terrorist organisation. The sort of language used by the Leader of the Opposition in condemning this visit was either hypocritical, in view of the policies that he earlier supported, or it marks a change of policy. We would like to hear from the Opposition whether it marks a change in policy to a more totalitarian approach as to who visits this country and who does not. The Government will continue with a policy which allows freedom of speech in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Treasurer without notice and without squalor. I refer the Treasurer specifically to the Christian Brethren Youth Hostel in Campsie, which provides accommodation to country youths who need to go to Sydney to find work and/or to study. This organisation now claims that it is facing a fringe benefits tax liability of $6,000 for the volunteer live-in couple-and their two children-who act as house parents for such young folk. I ask the Treasurer: Is he aware that this hostel has been advised by the Australian Taxation Office that it cannot claim the exemption for public benevolent institutions because it takes in only young men who agree to go to a church service of their own choice on Sundays? Is it the opinion of the Treasurer that the volunteers who maintain and raise--
—Order! The honourable gentleman may not ask the Treasurer for an opinion. He may not ask for the Government policy either.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. Is it correct that these volunteers who maintain and raise funds to keep these young people housed are greedy because they object to paying fringe benefits tax? Are they tax cheats and rip-off merchants? Finally, will the Treasurer refer this matter of whether this volunteer youth hostel should be liable to pay fringe benefits tax to Senator Richardson for his advice or at the least his comment?

—There is an exemption in the fringe benefits tax legislation in respect of institutions which are of benevolent nature. I should need to look to see whether such an institution is qualified in that respect. However, if it does not qualify the fringe benefits tax payable upon the rental accommodation of the people concerned would be diminished by the circumstances of the accommodation. If the accommodation is part of a hostel-type building where the quality of the accommodation is not akin to the quality of residential accommodation, the value of the accommodation therefore is so written down. That is why I should think that in the circumstances the honourable gentleman described the $6,000 mentioned is entirely unreasonable as an assessment and out of court on the part of the person who obviously was in touch with the honourable gentleman. I make the more general point that if people are subject to accommodation in these circumstances-be they employees of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals or the National Trust, or whoever-and the value of the accommodation is run down because of tourists going through the house, barking dogs outside, or whatever, the lower rental value is the value on which the fringe benefits tax is payable and, in all of these cases, that should be very modest indeed.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. Have the bulk billing procedures under Medicare been of great benefit to Australian families, particularly families with sick children?

—Of course, the most obvious advantages of bulk billing have accrued to the great majority of pensioners and social security beneficiaries in this country who are covered by the bulk billing procedures. In addition, we now have very detailed evidence which shows that the expansion of bulk billing in Sydney has been overwhelmingly in the working class and lower income suburbs. Doctors increasingly are making use of the bulk billing facility to deliver services without cost to families in need. In fact, the September figures show that for the first time-at least, for the first time without any accounting problems being involved-over 50 per cent of all medical services in this country were delivered through the direct billing process. That is bringing very real benefits, particularly to the less well off in the community.

—I refer the Treasurer to the continuing uncertainty surrounding the fringe benefits tax, especially after his announcement of various changes on 29 October. Given that nearly five weeks will have elapsed from the date of the announcement of changes until Parliament rises for the year, will the Treasurer give an assurance that the changes will be put into legislative form and introduced into the House this year so that taxpayers who have to make two payments of fringe benefits tax before Parliament resumes next year will be able to know exactly what is their liability under this taxation measure?

—I make the point more generally that it has been the practice of governments for years to announce and legislate changes to the tax law when practicable, when the laws can be drafted and when they can be introduced in the sittings of the Parliament. That does not diminish the force of the change or the force of the law. I am not entirely certain, without checking, what scheduling has been arranged; but I will let the honourable gentleman know.

—Can the Minister for Science give details of measures that are being taken by his Department to study the huge hole that has appeared in the ozone layer over Antarctica? Can he also inform the House of the consequences that may ensue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hole in the ozone layer over the Halley Base in Antarctica for a period of several weeks in the spring was first reported in Nature in 1985, and later in other media. Recent results show that in October this year the ozone content of the atmosphere over much of Antarctica was about half of that elsewhere. The values in October 1986 were 30 to 40 per cent less than they were in 1979. The most recent evidence suggests that a similar hole is starting to appear above the polar regions in the north-in the Arctic region. So far there has been no such extension of the hole over a temperate or populated region. But the implications, if a hole were to emerge, are particularly serious. As I will explain, the reasons are mysterious and quite uncertain. The hole over the Antarctic was approximately the size of the Australian mainland.

ANSWER.PARA: An investigation was carried out in the Antarctic by scientists from the United States of America. Two fundamental theories have been put forward. One is that it is a transient climatic phenomenon. The second is that it is caused by man-made pollution, for example, by fluorocarbon gases, oxides and nitrogen generated by burning fossil fuels or chloro-fluorocarbon gases. The question of which theory is more appropriate is still unclear. Curiously, the Du Pont Corporation in the United States, which had always been very defensive about the matter and said that the ozone hole could not possibly have anything to do with emissions from the use of fluorocarbons and other spray emissions, has now changed position and thinks that there could be serious implications.

The Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research-SCAR, which is a world-wide committee-has set up a specialist working committee on the depletion of ozones to provide international co-ordination of investigations of individual nations from 1986 to 1990. If the depletion of the ozone layer continues it may have the effect of disrupting the life cycles of marine plankton and fish larvae, of diminishing crop yields and of causing more cancers especially among humans, farm animals and other land-based species. The first measurements to confirm the depletion of the ozone layer came from Antarctic research and it is a pretty heartening confirmation of the importance of scientific programs being carried out in the Antarctic. However, the precise reason is not clear.

Dr Susan Solomon, of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, who led the recent team at McMurdo in the Antarctic, said that the evidence gathered so far does not point conclusively to any reason, either to the chloro-fluorocarbons or any other man-made material. Many American scientists believe that it is simply an unexpected climatic condition but it is something we certainly need to observe--

TALK.START.PARA: —Sun spots.

—It could conceivably be related to that but it indicates how uncertain is the operation of the climate and that we need internationally-of course Australia cannot do this on its own-increased scrutiny of the upper and lower atmospheres. I assure honourable members that if this ozone hole were to develop over a temperate zone it would have very serious consequences and few countries would be more disadvantaged than Australia.

—I refer the Minister for Primary Industry to the recent Industries Assistance Commission report that recommended no assistance be given to the Australian citrus industry that has suffered an unpre- cedented drop in returns. Will the Minister throw this report in the wastepaper basket and ensure that this vital regional industry receives appropriate support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say about the IAC report is that the industry and other interested parties made submissions to the IAC on aspects affecting the citrus industry. The report has been received and released and is being given consideration by the Government. We will make a decision as soon as possible and announce it as soon as practicable.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the Australian Customs Service is now examining whether orange juice concentrate from Brazil is being dumped in Australia and a preliminary finding is due soon. Before the break I pointed out to the House that imports of Brazilian juice were down by 24 per cent-what was coming into Australia had a different acid content than what we produce-that stocks as such were mainly of Australian origin and that this industry is highly protected already. The really big problem is the effect of the price of Brazilian juice translating through into the whole Australian structure and that is one of the matters the Government will be looking at.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Science. Is the Government concerned about reports that the `greenhouse' effect will raise ambient temperature to such an extent that sea levels will rise and flood coastal cities? Can the Minister inform the House whether these reports are soundly based?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, this is the second leg of a double. There is growing public interest and concern about the prospect of a change in world climate as a result of increased levels of certain trace gases in the atmosphere. The primary climate impact will involve a warming of the lower atmosphere due to what has been called the `greenhouse' effect and this, of course, will lead to variations in other elements of climate. The Australian Government has been well aware of the problem for some time. In 1976 it funded the establishment of a base line pollution station at Cape Grim in Tasmania as part of an associated world wide research program to study increasing `greenhouse' gas levels. That station at Cape Grim on the far north-west tip of Tasmania is managed jointly within my ministry by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Atmospheric Research and the Bureau of Meteorology.

ANSWER.PARA: Research programs in CSIRO show that indeed certain gases are increasing, the important ones being CO2, Freon-11, Freon-12 and methane. The first, of course, is due to the burning of fossil fuels; the second is man made and is used in various industrial processes; and the third is primarily of agricultural origin, especially from ruminant animals. There is no realistic prospect of influencing the steady and accelerating increases in the background concentrations of these gases which, more than anything else, are due essentially to increasing world population. Crude estimates have been made of the direct effect of higher carbon dioxide levels on plant productivity, on warming the atmosphere and on changing rainfall patterns and sea levels. Regional effects and the confidence to be given to these estimates need much further research. CSIRO is giving some priority to such studies and a specific program is being set up in the Division of Atmospheric Research.

However, I must emphasise that the consequences, at least for the next 50 years-or for the life of the Hawke Government-are not likely to be either catastrophic or even dramatic. There would need to be a very dramatic increase in ambient temperature to melt the Antarctic ice sheet which is generally about 2,000 metres thick. But if this were to happen, the consequences would of course be catastrophic. One problem to be examined is whether Asia, Africa and South America will adopt the same level of resource usage as is current in North America and Europe. I think for a whole number of economic reasons this is unlikely, but if it were to happen, it would have a very serious effect. This does reinforce the importance of thinking more seriously about the long term-something that the Opposition is not very good at-and taking appropriate preventative action for long term risk minimisation. Areas of immediate concern include coastal engineering, land development, water resources, agricultural economics and insurance. We have been warned. The printout, as they say, is on the wall and we have to take appropriate preventive long term action.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Ian Cameron,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Goodluck,Mr Hawker,Mr Rocher,Mr Ruddock and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned express our deepest concern over the government's discriminatory policies on overseas students which were contained in the 1986/87 Federal Budget. We register our strongest outrage and opposition to:
1. The introduction and subsequent increase of overseas students charge imposed on overseas students.
2. The proposed imposition of fees to secondary and TAFE overseas students.
3. The restrictive quota system on the tertiary institutions entry.
4. The heavy-handed deportation of overseas students who fail to pay their fees in time.

The overseas students program is an important education program to promote international goodwill and peace, especially among nations of Asia and Pacific region. The above mentioned policies have adverse effects on the objectives of overseas students program. Your petitioners therefore urge that the overseas students policies in the 1986-87 Budget be immediately reviewed.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin,Mr Gorman,Mr Snow and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
- in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
- that such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
- that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would:
- be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
- impede the development of new nuclear weapons
- decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
- inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to:
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Jakobsen,Mr Kent,Mr Staples and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Hawker and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mr Hawker and Mr Lloyd.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular:
the failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;
the abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18, even those still at school;
the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many larger families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI;
the dependent spouse rebate be retained;
the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore equitable provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of North Sydney respectfully showeth our strongest concern and objection to the Federal budget cuts in the English as a Second Language Program. The Federal Government holds the Constitutional responsibility for immigration and as such has an obligation towards immigrants and their children.
Further democratic governments have their obligation to provide for the Educational rights of every citizen.
To halve the ESL program is to renege on government responsibility and to disadvantage and, in fact, discriminate against tens of thousands of children from non-English speaking backgrounds.
Your petitioners humbly pray that funding of the ESL program be restored to at least the 1985 levels.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefits Tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker,Mr Rocher and Dr Watson.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should-

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are seriously concerned about the impact of the Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. It is unjust for any person to be liable for tax on benefits received by another person.
2. Compliance with FBT will increase administrative costs for all employers including Local, State and Federal Government Departments.
3. FBT is an inefficient tax, which will require the Tax Office to employ an army of bureaucrats.
4. FBT is inequitable because liability arises regardless of capacity to pay.
5. The FBT laws are extremely complex.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small businesses and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That the anomalous Fringe Benefits tax is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair on the grounds that-
it adversely affects business throughout Australia, including farms,
by creating a further tax burden it destroys incentive,
it has caused unemployment,
it is costly to administer and its complexities have caused confusion and widespread anger.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Fringe Benefits tax legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Fringe Benefits Tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The Fringe Benefits Tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament House. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will: Propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year'' (FIERY) as a vital action to ignite global co-operation for Worldpeace.
