PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. That the impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that persistent rumours suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensure no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs. Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We, the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the Government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act (as amended in 1985), and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the Government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations;
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their renumeration packages;
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business;
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should:
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices;
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes, and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
that the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
that the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
that the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth:
We most strongly oppose the use of the `Special Broadcasting Service' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

We are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on Radio 3EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
We respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.

Your petitioners therefore, strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: Matters Affecting the Ethnic Community
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled, the petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth opposition to cuts in English as a Second Language (ESL) teaching, the scrapping of the Multicultural Education Program, the amalgamation of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), and the abolition of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs (AIMA), as announced in the Federal Budget of August 19, 1986.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government will review and reverse its decision on these matters.
And your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the intention of the Hawke Government to unionise independent contractors, sub-contractors, the self-employed, partnerships, sole traders and family businesses will:
Remove the freedom of independent small business to:
(a) set their own prices
(b) work their own hours
(c) control their own businesses
(d) negotiate their own contracts; and
will create impossible working conditions which will include the payment of:
(a) union superannuation
(b) compensation
(c) payroll tax
(d) annual leave loadings
(e) public holiday loadings
(f) PAYE tax deductions
(g) limited incomes
(h) inflexible awards and conditions; and
(i) fixed hours of work.
We the undersigned call upon the Government to restore incentive and opportunity to the Australian economy and to abandon these coercive measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly object to the Government's decision to sell Australia's uranium to France and elsewhere particularly in view of:
all dangers to humankind inherent in the nuclear industry
continued nuclear bomb testing in the Pacific by France.

We regard the Government's proposed action as a complete negation of its stated policy for a Nuclear Free Pacific and request that the uranium is not sold and that all uranium mining ceases forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the Government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.

PETITION.TITLE: Cost of Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Our opposition to the proposed increase in the cost of a prescription, this increase will cause great hardship to many families Medical treatment is a necessity not a luxury.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the cost of a prescription remain at the current cost.
An your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing-related Poverty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of citizens of Australia shows that:
Approximately 100,000 Australians live on the verge of homelessness, dependent on government resources to survive, or sleep out of doors or in refuges.
Over 700,000 households, or in excess of 2 million Australians are living below the poverty line after paying their rent or mortgage costs.
In addition, there are thousands of households with special needs, such as the disabled, who are not well catered for in the private sector but who nevertheless require suitable housing.
Waiting lists for public housing have almost doubled in the past five years to 146,000 by June 1985. The list is expected to grow to some 250,000 by 1990.
We therefore ask that the Australian Government, as a highest priority:
undertake a campaign to bring the issue of poverty and, in particular, housing-related poverty, to the attention of the Australian public
increase expenditure on public housing through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, by at least 15% annually in real terms
increase rent relief payments for those on low incomes in the private rental market
use its influence with State and Territory governments to encourage them to increase their expenditures on public housing.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that they are opposed to the elimination, as from 1 November 1986, of a number of commonly used medications previously on the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives assembled call upon the Government to reject any proposal that discontinues the provision of free medications to pensioners.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Australian Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
Take the action necessary to create an Australian republic on or before 1st January 1988.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600. We your petitioners, humbly showeth:

That the wildlife species, in this case-the kangaroo, have a right to exist and flourish independently of human needs. For this reason alone we should not regard the kangaroo as a human resource nor contemplate commercial exploitation simply because more offspring are born each generation than can hope to survive.
Permissible cropping rates are unknown and the means of enforcing controls or protective legislation is completely ineffective and inadequate due to the widespread nature of the industry.
All Australians have a responsibility to our already declining wildlife.
We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will:
1. Ban the exports of products made from kangaroos.
2. Take action to see that State Governments prohibit the commercial killing of kangaroos.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Grace.

PETITION.TITLE: Secondary Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Western Australia call on the Commonwealth Government to reverse recent decisions which deny Secondary Allowances to Year 11 Students under the age of 16 years and make such allowances directly payable to students on attaining the age of 16.
This request is made on the basis that:
(i) Education benefits as part of income support benefits generally are a Commonwealth responsibility under the constitution.

(ii) It is the right of parents with children in Year 11 in Western Australia to receive the same benefit as parents with children at the equivalent stage of their education in other parts of Australia irrespective of their age.
(iii) This decision by the Commonwealth Government will impact most unfairly on the capacity of low income families in Western Australia to keep their children at school in Years 11 and 12.

(iv) Direct payment of the allowance to 16 year olds will make it easier for young people to leave home and bring more pressure on State Authorities to find alternative accommodation for them at the community and taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the Northern Territory of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation recently passed by Parliament is unfair and will prejudice the current working conditions of all Territorians.
1. It will increase both personal and company taxation.
2. It will undermine employment levels through reducing profitability and international competitiveness of industry.
3. It will result in price increases.
4. It will force employers to withdraw voluntary incentives to employees paid over and above existing payments.
5. It endangers stable industrial relations because of the potential for forced withdrawal of Fringe Benefits.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take such action as is necessary to rescind the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1986.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits and Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned petitioners of the electorate of Farrer, do respectfully show our opposition to the introduction of a Fringe Benefits Tax and Capital Gains Tax, and related legislation.
Your petitioners do humbly call for the repeal of both pieces of legislation. Such taxes are an additional burden upon small businesses, and lead to increased bureaucracy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the assembled Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.
We the humble petitioners at Warrnambool Institute Student Union, in the Federal electorate of Wannon respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of an Administration Charge of $250 for higher education students in Appropriation Bill 1986-87 (Volume 1, Page 98) is a regressive step for the Education system;
That the introduction of an Administration Charge will force students to withdraw from studies and thereby destroy the opportunity for them to complete their education;
That the Administration Charge is a form of Tuition Fees and as such destroys the principle of free education for all;
We the humble petitioners hereby request you to amend the Appropriation Bill 1986-87, so that the system of free education for all students will continue.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industries Assistance Commission's Recommendations for the Chemical Industry
PETITION.PARA: Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned employees of B. F. Goodrich Chemical Limited ask the Government not to adopt the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations for the chemical industry without modification, as any significant reduction in tariffs over a short period of time will adversely effect the long term viability of the Altona chemical complex. We pray that the Government not adopt the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations for the chemical industry without modification.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor, Lucas Heights, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Sutherland Shire respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian atomic energy establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986
Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1986
Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986
Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill 1986

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The cynicism and lack of principle displayed by the Government in its introduction and subsequent handling of the fringe benefits tax.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again it is the duty of the Opposition to raise the matter of the fringe benefits tax. This time we speak on behalf of all those Australians who are utterly sick of the sheer cynicism and lack of principle of the Government in the way it announced this tax, in the way it delayed its introduction into the House and in the way it has conducted itself since then-on again, off again, denying that there were any troubles, being dragged screaming to the point that two weeks ago it had to announce some changes which it claimed would remove the so-called unintended consequences of the tax. Where are we now? We have a whole new series of difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go to the heart of the matter of the cynicism and lack of principle I draw the attention of the House to a question asked in the House today by my colleague the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), who represents a constituency in the southern suburbs of Sydney. The honourable member specifically referred the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the Christian Brethren Youth Hostel in Campsie, which provides accommodation to country youths who need to go to Sydney to find work or to study. This organisation now claims that it is facing a fringe benefits tax liability of up to $6,000 for the volunteer live-in couple and two children who act as house parents and clean and cook meals for the resident boys each day.

It is true that the Treasurer introduced some changes earlier which freed benevolent institutions of the fringe benefits tax but this organisation, a Christian organisation, cannot be classified as a benevolent institution because it is a requirement that the boys admitted to the institution attend a church service of their own choice on Sundays. Because the purpose of the body being set up was Christian it is perfectly reasonable that that be a condition of entry. It is left to the boys which church service they choose. By this very commitment to a Christian principle the institution is obliged to pay the fringe benefits tax. So money which has to be raised partly from subscriptions, donations, from the public has to be used to pay tax to the Government. Such a situation is absolutely disgraceful. If we cannot go through a cleaning up of the legislation to remove such nonsenses we wonder what other nonsenses there are in the legislation. I must say that there are many.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been trying to sell this tax. Trying to sell the fringe benefits tax is like selling the benefits of leprosy. The Government is doing so using $2m of taxpayers' money on grossly misleading advertisements which claim that the tax does not affect low income people. That is a palpable nonsense as I shall demonstrate later. Those advertisements, introduced at a cost of $2m to the public, also create class division in Australia. The very nature of the advertisements suggests that the lowly-paid workers are being ground into the dust by those higher up the managerial ladder. At a time when we are trying to engender a spirit of co-operation between employers and employees to try to get this country moving again, when work practices have to be sorted out, when the Government through other arms is trying to engender this spirit of co-operation in the work force we see the stupid, divisive class war-type advertisements which are paid for with taxpayers' money.

After the first advertisement, which shows a pyramid of workers being ground into the dust by those higher up the ladder and misleadingly claims that those on lower incomes are not affected by the tax-they are-the second advertisement shows two people, one holding a glass of beer, presumably to denote a worker, and the other person wearing a suit. This is tending once again to depict some form of class division and it tries to set one Australian against another. The irony in that advertisement, which was pointed out to me by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), is that this Government has taxed the pants off the beer drinker. Every six months the beer tax goes up automatically under this Government. It has the infernal hide and cynicism to use a picture of a man holding a glass of beer in an advertisement in its divisive attempt to set one Australian against another.

What really gets my goat is that the Government is doing this with our money-with the taxpayers' money. It is misleading the public and trying to sell something that cannot be sold. My friend the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) has sent me a report from the Flinders News of 4 November 1986 which tells us about a whirlwind tour by the Prime Minister. The dateline is Port Pirie and the article states:
The Prime Minister Mr Hawke visited the three Iron Triangle cities of Whyalla, Port Augusta and Port Pirie in a flurry of hand-shaking last Thursday.

This is the man who went out into the bush near Blayney last year after these taxes were introduced and told the farmers there that they would not be disadvantaged, that he would go back and talk to the Treasurer about removing the anomalies in the fringe benefits tax that affected them. He listened to everything they said. He got a whole stack of favourable publicity on television but he came back here and did nothing for the farmers. For month after month the Opposition asked why it was equitable to put a tax on farmers, who were not earning anything in current international markets, which had to be paid before they even earned a profit, because the fringe benefits tax-any Australian who does not know this has to know this from now on-is paid not after profits but before profits.

Farmers expected that the Prime Minister would come back here and do something to tell the Treasurer to get off their backs, but he did nothing. Even after the so-called anomalies have been removed, are the farmers exempted from the tax? Of course they are not. The tax still applies to work related costs on the farms as it does in small business, in mines and in various other areas. The Prime Minister had the hide to say, as reported in the Flinders News, that he believed the changes in the fringe benefits tax announced last week would remove any criticisms from the business community. Some hope! He went on to say, and this just goes to show what a pixieland he lives in:
In any case the FBT won't affect farmers very much.

Heaven forbid, what have we got? Time and again the Prime Minister goes out and claims that he is going to do something and time and again he comes back and fails. He kids himself that he has done something and he goes around expecting to be believed. Two weeks ago we reached the absolute pits in this debate when the Treasurer, speaking on the Michael Schildberger program on 3 November, said this:
If any Commonwealth Government tried to levy the FBT on employees, the industrial disruption that would follow would have had the employers up to Canberra a week later.

That is one of the most disgraceful admissions ever made by a Minister in any Australian government. This Government cynically and without principle decided, for purely political reasons, that it could not tax the people who were enjoying benefits and therefore it decided in the interests-it became clear subsequently in its advertisements-of class division and the Australian Labor Party envy principle to levy the tax in the most complicated and damaging possible way on every employer in the country. That is an absolute disgrace. The Treasurer is responsible once again for that and he has not even got the guts to come into the House and defend himself. He has sent the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) in to give his usual speech. He may as well just have his speech included in Hansard as we already know what it is. We have not even got the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) in here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about the real issues.

—The real issue, my dear friend, is that you will not be here next time. If the honourable member for Maribyrnong would like to listen for a moment I will tell him what the power broker of the right wing faction of the ALP thinks about the fringe benefits tax. I refer, of course, to Senator Richardson, who is a close adviser to the Prime Minister and a former friend of the Treasurer. Oh, the Treasurer has come into the House. We have finally flushed him out. Senator Richardson used to be a friend of the Treasurer before the Treasurer said in the Caucus room that Senator Richardson had a PhD in greed. They were mates. Senator Richardson is still a friend and adviser of the Prime Minister. He spoke to the Australian Labor Party conference in the Hunter Valley only at the weekend. He said this:

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give you an example that where I still think there's improvement to be made in our review of the FBT if you look at the problems faced by Commonwealth Bank employees it is best crystallised. There are some 36,000 people working for the Commonwealth Bank, 2 per cent of them earn salaries of $28,000 or more. What we're talking about here by Australian standards is a low paid work force. The average salary is around about $18,000, less than average weekly earnings. Now the salaries in that bank have been depressed for years because they were getting another benefit, the benefit of low interest loans. But in the regime that faces Australia today they can't get a big pay increase to make up for losing a low interest loan and then we make a decision-
that is the Government, Senator Richardson's own Government-
that affects the low interest loan as well.

Senator Richardson then described the Commonwealth Bank employee meetings all round Australia which had an extraordinary attendance. He said that those employees are not like members of the Builders Labourers Federation. He continued:

when 36,000 white collar employees, not front line radical trotskies, but bank employees, bank tellers and the rest turn out in those numbers you've got a problem and when a 20-year old bank employee at the Sydney Entertainment Centre bags our government and gets a standing ovation you've got real problems. Now I'd like to see us address those problems.

The basic problem is there from the start. The Treasurer claimed that this was a tax designed to stop the big time rorts. The Treasurer came into the House and talked about people going in the train with a brown paper bag full of sandwiches and looking out the window at those who were driving their Mercedes-Benz motor cars to work. All I can say is that after all this, after all the pages of legislation, after all the guides to employers, after all the pages of rulings-with all the legislation to come-the people at the top of the ladder still have their benefits and the lowly paid workers such as those in the Commonwealth Bank do not have them. They are the ones who have been hit. At the same time that the Treasurer talked about brown paper bags and the plight of the lowly paid workers he had to justify in this House why he claimed $17,000 in travel allowance. He tried to explain to us and the rest of Australia how he could write down on the form that his place of residence was in Sydney when he actually lives in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't compound your dishonesty.

—I am raising this as a very serious issue because in the ordinary meaning of the word for anybody we all have an understanding of what we mean when we fill in the particular form and state where we live. I would not be raising this matter in this House in this way if the Treasurer himself had not lectured us day after day on the rorts that people were supposed to have.
—Order! If the honourable member for Mackellar wishes to make an attack on another member he has to do that by substantive motion. That is the only thing I draw to the honourable member's attention.
—I accept your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar does not need any help from his colleagues on his left.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, which I have just tabled, has the title `A Taxing Problem'. It results from the review by the Committee of five efficiency audit reports of the Auditor-General. These reports contained his conclusions and recommendations resulting from the examination of various aspects of the operations of the Australian Taxation Office. These audit reports are among the most significant and disturbing of their type. Without some Government initiative-which the Committee recommends that it now take-it is probably only the Auditor-General who, because of his statutory powers, is able to conduct such a penetrating, external examination into aspects of the administration of the Australian Taxation Office. In reviewing the reports the Committee's attention was drawn to broad issues associated with the administration of this most important Government office.

SPEECH.PARA: Administrative Changes Needed

The theme of the Committee's report is that substantial administrative changes need to be made in the Australian Taxation Office if it is to effectively implement the legislation for which it is responsible and, using its own words, to `gather the revenue'. Only if this is done will a satisfactory level of taxpayer compliance be achieved, and only by the achievement of a satisfactory level of compliance will the tax burden be spread in accordance with the legislative intention of this Parliament.
Simplify Tax Law

In spite of recent changes to the law, the tax collection system remains in need of further reform-that kind of reform which leads to a simpler system which all Australians can understand more easily than is now the case. Over recent months not only the decisions of this Parliament but also those of the administration have added further complexity to an already complex system. This increasing complexity, coupled with an unsatisfactory level of ambiguity, means that tax law has become a significant concern to tax collector and taxpayer alike. The conclusion of the Committee contained in its report is that review by the Australian Taxation Office of existing taxation law is urgently required.
Crisis Management

The Australian Taxation Office argued that the problems identified by the Auditor-General and probed by the Committee were, to a significant degree, the result of the preoccupation of senior staff in dealing with the growth of tax avoidance and evasion schemes and the implementation of the freedom of information legislation and other tasks heaped upon it by Parliament. The Committee is of the view that the problems of the Australian Taxation Office are more serious than this explanation for what appears to the Committee to be a crisis management approach.

There are serious shortcomings within the Australian Taxation Office's administrative philosophies which reflect in the way it operates. These result in the revenue which should be collected, not being collected. They also impose unnecessary costs upon taxpayers by requiring them to provide information which is not used in the naive belief that this requirement alone will result in increased taxpayer compliance. There are a number of other aspects of the Committee's report which I particularly wish to draw to the attention of the House.
Computerisation

Firstly, I turn to the Australian Taxation Office's lack of computerisation. The Committee found that the lack of computerisation, entwined with a continuation of labour intensive work practices, has retarded the Australian Taxation Office's efficient operation. The Committee concluded that the Australian Taxation Office has failed to acquire adequate data processing equipment. We were told `their data base is woefully inadequate' and that `it is operating in a computer environment that was planned in the early 1970s'. That would be like the Commonwealth car pool operating in the automobile environment of the T-model Ford. It seems that poor internal guidance effectively nullified any substantial implementation of new technologies. The result of this was that over a 10-year period, the Australian Taxation Office underspent by $49m its appropriation for computer equipment, and as a consequence, failed to process data available to it, and where it did so it often used highly labour intensive procedures.

Though for so long the Australian Taxation Office did not fully appreciate the potential of computerisation, the Committee acknowledges that the ATO has now set about developing new ADP strategies. So that the ATO does not again fall behind the times and the technologies, the Committee has recommended that priority setting mechanisms be established to review and report regularly on its ADP operations, actual, proposed and potential.
Alternative Collection Systems

Secondly, I draw the attention of the House to the Committee's recommendation that the Australian Taxation Office undertake a study of the cost effectiveness of alternative collection systems, with particular attention being given to the advantages of a generalised withholding tax structure. Coupled with this proposal, the Committee has recommended that the Australian Taxation Office, as a matter of urgency, advise the Government-maybe not for the first time-on the effectiveness of a withholding tax on interest paid to Australian residents as compared to the present method of tax collection based on taxpayer reporting of income derived in this way. Many forms of withholding tax are currently being used. The most common is the pay as you earn requirement applicable to wages and salaries under which employers deduct at source the tax due by their employees. The withholding tax method is, however, also used to collect tax due by overseas residents on dividends and interest payable to them from Australian sources. The prescribed payments tax is by nature a form of withholding tax. In evidence to the Committee, the Commissioner of Taxation agreed that a withholding tax could be more effective than traditional collection techniques when he said:
An appropriate system of deduction at source could raise more revenue than an information reporting system.

Based on Australian Bureau of Statistic figures, the Australian Audit Office has estimated that tax revenue forgone because of the failure under a reporting system of taxpayers to disclose dividend and interest income is in the range of $308m to $512m a year. These estimates were not disputed by the Tax Office. Indeed, it acknowledged that non-disclosure of interest was a major problem. The Treasury informed the Committee that, were a withholding tax to replace the present information reporting system, it could `bring in about two-thirds of the amount of tax evaded on undisclosed interest'. Furthermore, it appeared from the evidence before the Committee that not only would a withholding tax regime collect more revenue but it would also be far less costly to administer from the point of view of both taxpayer and tax collector.
Tax Identification System

Thirdly, the Committee believes that there is a need for a high integrity taxpayer identification system. Such a system would lead to substantial improvements in the ATO's information and checking systems and this, in turn, would generate greater tax revenues through increased taxpayer compliance. In spite of the fact that a tax file numbering system is well suited to this purpose, the system now used by the ATO was not, as it could have been, designed with the necessary degree of integrity. This design failure is yet another in the series of opportunities squandered by the Tax Office. The Committee has recommended that to ensure maximum taxpayer compliance the Tax Commissioner establish a high integrity identification system of his own. This, it believes, should be done whether the Australia Card is introduced or not.
Joint Management Review

Fourthly, I return to the issues raised in the introduction to this statement, namely, the need for substantial administration changes in the ATO. The Commissioner was critical of the fact that the Audit Office looked at particular segments of the Tax Office without having regard to the whole area of Tax Office operations. If this criticism was meant to imply that the reports unfairly reflected on the Tax Office in that other, unaudited areas of the Tax Office were operating at a high level of efficiency, the Committee rejects such an assertion. The Committee, on the evidence before it, believes that wherever the Auditor-General had looked in the Tax Office he would have found significant problems. In the light of the poor standard of Tax Office management the Expenditure Committee recommends that the Government establish a joint management review to investigate the overall performance and operation of the Australian Taxation Office and that Parliament be informed of the outcome of the review.

In conclusion, I want to thank all members of the Committee's staff who assisted in the conduct of the inquiry and the drafting of the report. I would like to thank the members of the Hansard staff who took down the record of the evidence. In thanking members of the Committee, I wish to single out Greg Burgess. His substantial contribution was very much appreciated by members of the Committee. I hope that the response to the Committee's report will be a simpler, fairer and more efficient tax collection system. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation continues the bipartisan support for international maritime conventions relating to pollution and safety. The Protection of the Sea Legislation Amendment Bill amends four Commonwealth Acts to implement more completely the 1973 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, commonly known as MARPOL. Legislation to implement annexes I and II was passed in 1983. This covers discharges of oil and noxious liquid substances. Earlier this year further legislation increased coverage of these annexes to the Australian territorial sea and coastal waters. That was done pending State legislation. I understand that that State legislation is under way. This Bill enables annexes III, IV and V to be implemented by complementary Federal, State and Territory legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Annex III requires that there be special containers on board ship to hold specific substances. Their discharge at sea is prohibited except where the safety of the ship or its crew is at risk. The Navigation Act 1912 is being amended to incorporate this annex. Annex IV covers the discharge of sewage by all Australian ships over 200 tonnes or carrying more than 10 people. No discharge is permitted in the Great Barrier Reef area. Annex V covers pollution from garbage and there is a prohibition on the dumping of synthetic ropes and fishing nets. Minimum distances off-shore have been set in relation to the degree of degradability, once again with a prohibition on dumping in the Great Barrier Reef area. The Bill also amends annex II to include changes agreed to at the December International Maritime Organisation meeting to implement the 1984 protocol to the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage. These changes include new insurance requirements to cover civil liability and this, in turn, will mean an increased cost for insurance for shipowners. Protocol I of the MARPOL Convention is also amended to incorporate new, comprehensive, mandatory reporting requirements.

The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) stated that at the Australian Transport Advisory Council meeting there was unanimous support for these provisions and that industry also had agreed. I have contacted the relevant State Ministers in Queensland, the Northern Territory and Tasmania, and a number of industry organisations. They, as the Minister said, support the legislation. Their only comments concern such things as a related, but I suppose not specific, problem concerning this legislation-that is, greatly increased Commonwealth charges for garbage services, irrespective of whether those garbage services have to be used-the problem already mentioned of increased insurance charges, some problems with the remeasuring of ships, and doubts as to whether annex IV will be fully implemented internationally. Evidently, there are problems in Norway and the United States. Mr Deputy Speaker, the Opposition continues the bipartisan attitude to this legislation and therefore supports the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to have the opportunity to speak today in support of the Protection of the Sea Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. As a person who spent a number of years in the late 1960s and early 1970s working in the waterfront industry, I am well aware of the pollution that can take place in our harbours and off-shore waters. I am, therefore, extremely pleased to see this legislation brought before the Parliament. I feel that it will be applauded by those in this House, and in the community at large, who care about the delicate marine environment that surrounds our island continent of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence the legislation will amend four Commonwealth Acts to facilitate the implementation of a number of anti-pollution measures which have been incorporated in international conventions to which Australia is a signatory. The Bill also contains amendments to penalties provided for in the Navigation Act 1912 and the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983. Being an island continent, we rely almost exclusively on the shipping industry for transportation of our exports and imports. Trade with other nations is the life- blood of our country and, to a large degree, depends on an efficient and cost effective method of transporting goods and materials between Australia and our trading partners. The maritime industry, particularly the Australian maritime industry, provides this vital connection with the world at large.

In the first three years of the Hawke Labor Government there has been a renaissance in the Australian maritime industry. This is in no small part due to the approach of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), who has fostered and promoted the resurgence of a strong and competitive Australian maritime industry after many years of neglect by successive coalition governments. I pay tribute to the Minister for his efforts in this area and I also pay tribute to the good sense of maritime unions and their membership which have co-operated in an outstanding fashion with the Government and with maritime employers to create the environment in which the Australian maritime industry can flourish. This is yet another example of what can be achieved when governments, unions and employers sit down seriously to attempt to resolve problems in a co-operative manner. This is something that the pedlars of conflict and confrontation on the other side of the House will never understand. They should hang their heads in shame for they would see industries like the Australian maritime industry destroyed rather than change their perverse views and policies on industrial relations.

Our reliance on shipping as the carrier of our international trade brings with it a whole set of problems which need to be addressed. One major problem is, of course, pollution of the marine environment which can be accidental, incidental or deliberate. With approximately 6,000 ship visits to our shores each year the magnitude of the problem becomes apparent. Some would argue that, whilst pollution of the oceans can be damaging, its effects are not irreversible. This is to a degree correct. There is in fact an inbuilt capacity within ecosystems to recover from some forms of pollution. However, this is not so in all cases and surely prevention is the best cure.

Unfortunately, for many years the human species has used the 78 per cent of the world's surface that is water as a repository of its wastes. The world's oceans and waterways were seen as little more than massive sinks into which we deposited all of our unwanted by-products and rubbish. Over the years, attitudes have changed and by and large this type of behaviour is no longer tolerated. It is now well understood that the ocean's capacity endlessly to accept wastes is not unlimited and within this realisation has come legislation to govern the disposal of wastes at sea.

One of the areas most sensitive to the effects of pollution, and also one of the areas most productive in terms of its ability to support life, is the shallow waters of the continental shelves. Unfortunately, these are also the areas where the input of wastes are at their highest. It is estimated that as much as 240,000 tonnes of sewage and 3,750 tonnes of garbage can be dumped in our waters per annum without fear of prosecution. This is indeed an undesirable activity and I believe that the vast majority of Australians would wish to see an end to it. The measures in this legislation will go a long way towards reducing the risk of pollution in our coastal waters.

The Bill will facilitate the implementation of 1985 amendments to annex II and Protocol I of the International Convention for Prevention of Pollution from Ships-the MARPOL Convention. The first covers noxious liquids carried in bulk and the second sets out pollution reporting requirements. The Bill also will assist in the implementation of annexes III, IV and V of the MARPOL Convention as well as the 1984 Protocol to the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage. The details of these annexes and protocols are set out in the explanatory memorandum which accompanies this Bill, so there is no need for an explanation from me on the finer details. The Minister covered these points in his second reading speech. I am sure that he will discuss the finer points in his summary when he is replying to the second reading debate. Suffice it for me to say that all of these measures have had the support of bodies involved in the maritime industry, including the Australian Transport Advisory Council and the former Marine and Ports Council of Australia. It should also be remembered that the MARPOL Convention was originally ratified in Australia in 1974 after close co-operation with the States and Northern Territory. In relation to annexes III, IV and V of the MARPOL Convention, it is proposed that continuing consultations will be undertaken with the States and the Northern Territory to ensure the development of uniform legislation.

It is proposed that the Commonwealth will legislate to control discharges from Australian ships on the high seas and that the States and Northern Territory legislate to prohibit all discharges from ships in coastal waters. This close co-operation will give us uniform legislation which will provide the protection required for Australian coastal waters, and we will also be playing a responsible role in protecting the open oceans.

A further function of the Bill will be to ensure that adequate compensation is available to persons who suffer oil pollution damage from ships carrying oil in bulk as cargo. The liability limits established in the 1969 civil liability convention have become, with inflation, inadequate. The 1984 protocol to this convention addresses this problem by setting new limits and also by providing a mechanism by which limits can be increased in future. This legislation will ensure the control of ship-sourced pollution in Australian waters and will also ensure that adequate compensation is available when pollution occurs.

I believe that this course of action deserves the support of both sides of the House. It is gratifying to see that it has received bipartisan support despite the usual diatribe from the honourable member for Northern Territory (Mr Everingham). But this is not new; it is something which we on this side of the House are getting used to. This course of action has the support of State and Territory governments and also the support of environmentally conscious Australians.

I pay a tribute to the maritime unions because of the constructive role that they have played and particularly because of their positive and objective approach in discussions with the Government and the Minister for Transport. We are now getting to the stage where we really have a viable shipping industry. The maritime unions can hold their heads high for the positive approach that they have taken to bring this about. I congratulate the Minister for Transport for introducing this legislation. I have no difficulty at all in commending this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Protection of the Sea Legislation Amendment Bill is a very important Bill and I am a little disappointed that there are not more members listed to speak on it. I was asked earlier why I wanted time to speak on the Bill as I come from a landlocked electorate. I want to do so because passing through my electorate is the magnificent Hawkesbury-Nepean River which flows into the beautiful sea that surrounds this country and I believe that that river needs to be given considerable protection from the problems confronting it. I am also interested in this legislation as I am the Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation and I therefore felt it necessary to speak on this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: I would first like to make a couple of comments about the oceans. I have done a little research which has revealed that nearly three quarters of the earth is covered by the sea. As has already been mentioned, the sea is the unique asset of our small world. As far as we know no other star or planet has water on its surface. Only minute traces of water in liquid state have been found anywhere within reach of our telescopes or space probes. Nearly four-fifths of all the plants and animals on earth live in the shallow coastal seas fringing the continents. They yield almost nine-tenths of the world's annual harvest of fish and shellfish. Countless minute plants drift in the waters, staining them green. Millions of tiny animals graze these floating pastures and in turn are eaten by the huge schools of prowling fish. Seabirds skim above the waves scooping up prey. On the seabed forests of undulating seaweed cling to the rocks and a host of creatures filter the water for food.

Today we are dealing with how we can protect the complex ecosystems and food chains that exist in the seas and oceans surrounding this continent and for which we are therefore responsible. I use the word responsible deliberately. We should be clear in this place that we are stewards over these vast, beautiful and bountiful seas and oceans. We are stewards firstly to the people of Australia who have given us the power to develop the necessary laws in these areas. But ultimately I believe we are stewards to Almighty God, our Creator, to whom we are ultimately accountable, whether we believe it or not, for the care we take in both caring for and developing the resources of the seas around us. Indeed Madam Speaker, every day, prays in this House for such wisdom. Jacques Cousteau has suggested that one of the great conservation and resource questions before humanity today is: Can the sea help mankind survive? What is more, can it help man not only to survive but also to lead a full and rewarding life; in other words to live rather than to exist? Cousteau is, of course, referring to the still underutilised potential of the sea as a source of food, and high protein food in particular.

This legislation is part of a continuing effort by this Parliament, under governments of both the Australian Labor Party and the coalition, to fulfil the responsibilities we have in terms of that stewardship of which I have spoken. It is part of an ongoing response to the questions which Cousteau and others have raised around the world. The Opposition has always supported the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, or MARPOL. In 1983 we supported legislation covering Convention annexes I and II, which covered oil and noxious liquids. Earlier this year legislation which increased coverage of this to Australia's territorial sea and coastal waters was also supported by the Opposition. This Bill will enable the remaining annexes III, IV and V to be implemented by complementary State, Commonwealth and Territory legislation. These annexes cover the discharge of sewage from Australian ships over 200 tonnes or carrying more than 10 people. They cover pollution from garbage and the dumping of synthetic ropes and fishing nets, and they deal with the responsibilities and liabilities of ship owners in regard to the pollution of our seas and oceans. The legislation also provides for the special protection of the Great Barrier Reef, and we are all very glad to hear that.

The Opposition supports this legislation without hesitation. Its support reflects its deep and common sense approach to conservation in general and it shows that where the Government moves beyond the grandstanding or politically motivated conservation action of the type we have seen in regard to Tasmania and Kakadu of late, it will win bipartisan support. In my discussions on this Bill one interesting point was noted concerning the problem of sewage discharge, and I refer to it as my last comment on this policy area. It seems strange that we should be drafting legislation which establishes responsibilities, liabilities and substantial penalties for the discharge of sewage from ships when, the beaches and coastal waters in my own State regularly see the discharge of sewage whenever the unions choose to use raw sewage discharges through strike action to place pressure on the Government. In my final sentence I suggest quite strongly that to be consistent in this regard the Government should discuss liabilities and penalties in that situation with State Ministers as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the House are pleased to see that the Opposition is supporting the Protection of the Sea Legislation Amendment Bill. As previous speakers have said, the matter of the protection of the marine environment is of concern to the Australian community at large. It is a truism that the marine environment is one that most Australians come to enjoy at some stage during their lives. It is also true that at this time of the year, when summer holidays are approaching, the marine environment represents the environment to which most people turn for their recreation. SPEECH.PARA: We recognise that the marine environment caters for a number of roles, and let me refer to them. For example, by definition the marine environment has a role in transport. In that sense it provides some degree of conflict between that role and other roles, but the transport role is quite central and significant and it has been a very historical role. The marine environment also provides a recreational role and a tourism role. Anyone listening to this debate would know that the role of tourism is central in the America's Cup which is presently being held off Fremantle in my home State of Western Australia. As I have indicated, the environment also provides that recreational role for people so they can go to the seaside and enjoy it. It also has a commercial role with respect to fishing, and fishing is of concern not only to those involved in that industry but also to those who enjoy the products of it. Where there are conflicting environmental roles of that nature, we will find that as a government we have to make decisions to try to resolve the difficulties and differences in those roles. It is in this context that, when debating the Protection of the Sea Legislation Amendment Bill and the ratification of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, the MARPOL Convention, we, as a government and as a parliament-the Opposition is supporting this legislation-believe that certain protocols ought to be adhered to with respect to transport activity.

Certain matters ought to be dealt with very severely if, for instance, people transgress in relation to that transport. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) was quite correct when he listed those issues. Very often we find that spills at sea or the results of other activities undertaken by people at sea have a detriment. In my own electorate of Stirling, which has the coastal beaches of Scarborough and Trigg, initially quite a bit of waste was washed up on to those beaches as a result of the America's Cup elimination trials. People have heard of the breeze called the `Fremantle Doctor' which is a prevailing south west wind. In fact there was an amount of material washed up on the beaches. I am pleased to say that the State Government and the Marine and Harbours Department were very alert to this, and when local residents raised this problem it was dealt with very effectively. The State Government, through its appropriate authorities, very sensibly deals with the potential for marine pollution. When there is a large spectator fleet and a larger number of competing yachts, it only follows that there is a potential for marine pollution. The State Government has very sensibly planned ahead in trying to cover that problem.

We are more fortunate in Western Australia than people in Sydney, as we do not have the sewer outfall that is really a curse of life to surfers and to beach goers. Western Australia does not have that degree of sewer outfall into the ocean. That is an example that we in this place ought to bear in mind when we talk about marine pollution.

Earlier this year there was a quite substantial oil spill in Western Australia. It occurred in July and resulted from a breakage of an oil pipeline. The Fremantle Port Authority, with the Marine and Harbours Department, had a real life situation to deal with. It turned out that with the use of mechanical booms to control the oil spill they were able to achieve success in mopping up the spill. In this case the authorities concerned, the BP and Shell oil companies, also acted responsibly; they recognised that they had a responsibility. We were more fortunate in this sense because we knew the source of the pollution and also because we had responsible authorities which were prepared to say, at the government and private levels, that we had a problem which should be dealt with. That leads me back to the legislation. Very often there will be irresponsible masters of ships who are prepared to discharge pollutants into the ocean. In that sense we have an international arrangement which this legislation specifically addresses. When we talk to people who are affected by marine spills as we were with the spill in July in Western Australia, it is important to note that there was quick action and whilst the clean-up operation was bedevilled with fairly strong winds it ultimately resulted in a satisfactory resolution. The West Australian of Tuesday, 29 July, stated:
As the clean-up operation continued in Fremantle yesterday, unpredictable northerly winds had made it difficult to control the slick that had escaped into Cockburn Sound.
By late evening part of the slick measuring three kilometres long, a metre wide and five centimetres thick was washed up on Garden Island.

People who have been involved with spills will recognise that what was on the beach was not just something that is like the oil that is normally used in motor vehicles; it is very tarry and sticky at that stage and very difficult to handle. With the development of what I refer to as detergents for cleaning up oil spills the public has the notion that if detergent is produced it will solve the problem. In fact, many environmentalists would argue quite convincingly that the detergents themselves can have a greater negative environmental impact than can the original oil spill. It does create a problem, and that is why I referred earlier to the fact that very often the use of mechanical booms is a more effective way of controlling marine oil spills in particular because oil floats in water and can be contained and gradually mopped up. It is an issue in which everyone in Australia, if I could use the term, has a vested interest because as I began to say at the outset the beaches represent the important recreational environment for so many people. This brings me to an important issue in this legislation; the question of drilling in sensitive areas. We need to recognise that with many activities we undertake, be they mining activities in the case of oil drilling, be they transport activities in the case of shipping, or be they commercial activities in the case of fishing, there are side effects of which we have to be conscious. The crucial point about this legislation is that it says that this country has a responsibility in those respects and that we will honour that responsibility. In the context of this, it is important to say that both sides of Parliament recognise that this is an important issue. Many people in the community say that members of Federal Parliament spend a lot of time arguing with one another. It is proper that there should be argument and it is proper to point out that consensus and bipartisan support take place. It is taking place in the debate on this legislation.

I close by saying that one of the great challenges we will face in the future in the marine environment is the continual need to make decisions between a variety of conflicting goals. The transport goal is one; the tourism goal is another. There has been considerable conflict over Scarborough Beach, which is a metropolitan beach in my electorate. There has been debate about developments there and about the need to boost the economy by having tourism projects. We will find that there will be continuing pressure. It is my view that debates such as this are very important and central because they draw to the public mind a realisation that we as a community have to make decisions, make choices and take stands about issues that we think are important. It is also my view that we tend to take our beaches for granted. We tend to assume that they will always be there. We tend to assume that they will always be in pristine conditions. It will not always be so unless we are careful and conscious of our duty of care towards the marine environment. This legislation specifies one aspect of that duty of care, but I think that is only part of it. The other part is that we as a community have a responsibility to ensure that we do not leave rubbish on the beach and that we treat the beaches with respect.

It is one thing for the national Government to take legislative action and it is another for the community as a whole to recognise its responsibilities for its own area of activities; in this case the beaches. We will do our bit; we will pass legislation. We are saying to the transport industry that the legislation has an impact for it. We are also saying to the wider community to recognise that it has responsibility. Beaches are for everyone and are to be taken care of. We do not need crazy development or excessive development; we need a sensible responsibility by the community to that very important environment. I am pleased to commend this legislation to the House.
