TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill 1986 is to empower the Treasurer to make agreements on behalf of Australia to purchase, in the first instance, 815 additional shares of the capital stock of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and, secondly, 14,560 additional shares of the capital stock of the International Finance Corporation. These provisions relate to the Government's obligations under its membership of the World Bank group and, in particular, of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation. The articles of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development were drawn up in 1944 at the Bretton Woods Conference. Membership of the bank, which began operations a couple of years later, in 1946-47, is restricted to members of the International Monetary Fund which ratify the articles of the bank and accept the terms laid down by it. The purpose of establishing the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which became known as the World Bank, was to promote the international flow of capital for productive purposes and to assist in financing the rebuilding of nations that had been devastated in the Second World War.

SPEECH.PARA: Lending for productive projects which will lead to economic growth in its less developed member countries is now the bank's main objective. The bank is also attempting to increase the proportion of its lending which directly assists the poorest people in the developing countries. As at 31 March this year, effective loans by the World Bank totalled $US89,084m-a very substantial amount. The authorised capital stock of the bank, which was originally $US10,000m, was successively increased to $41,016m in 1978. A doubling of the authorised capital to the equivalent of 70,500 million special drawing rights was approved in 1979. A further capital increase to accommodate the People's Republic of China brought the authorised capital to SDR71,650m when the People's Republic of China became a member. The authorised capital at present stands at $US71,650m.

The members' capital subscriptions are divided into three parts which are relevant to understanding the nature of the contribution which Australia will be making. One per cent of the total authorised capital is payable by member countries in gold or US dollars. Nine per cent is payable in the member's own currency. Ninety per cent, which has not been paid, may be called up when required. So when we talk in terms of the total monetary commitment of member countries of the World Bank we need to keep in mind that 90 per cent of its total authorised capital has not been called up and would be called up only when and if required. The bank obtains most of its funds from borrowing on international capital markets. In effect, it uses its callable capital-that is, the capital which member countries undertake to subscribe-as its security. As at 31 March this year the bank had outstanding borrowings which totalled almost $US67,000m. Membership of the IBRD at present stands at 149, representing countries at all levels of development throughout the world.

The second element of this legislation is to provide, as I indicated, for Australia to purchase 14,500 additional shares in the capital stock of the International Finance Corporation. It is apparent that the purpose of doing this is not only to build up the authorised capital of these international institutions but also to increase their capacity to borrow money using the approved capital at call as security. The International Finance Corporation was established in 1956 and became a specialised agency of the United Nations in the following year. Although it is affiliated with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, it has a separate legal entity and its capital is entirely separate from that of the bank. It borrows most of its funds for relending from the IBRD.

In 1977 it expanded its operations into more developing member countries, particularly the lower income countries, and into new sectors such as agribusiness, energy and minerals. At 31 March this year investments by the IFC totalled $42,364m in 74 countries. The IFC is empowered to invest in productive private or partly governmental enterprises in association with private investors, and without government guarantee of repayment in cases where sufficient private capital is not available on reasonable terms, and to serve as a clearing house to bring together investment opportunities, private capital-both foreign and domestic-and experienced management. Its special purpose is to promote the growth of the private sector and to assist productive private enterprises in its developing member countries where such enterprises can advance economic development. The membership of the IFC stands at 127.

Australia is entitled to subscribe to 745 shares under the special capital increase and to 70 shares under the increase in certain subscriptions-that is, a total of 815 shares-to the IBRD. Those shares are valued at $US98.32m. In practice, as I indicated, the callable capital of the bank-I do not think that it has ever been called-serves as security for the extensive borrowing operations of the World Bank on world capital markets. There is also agreement for the purchase of those additional shares of capital stock of the International Finance Corporation. In relation to this, its represents a doubling of the authorised capital stock from the $650m which had been approved in 1977.

Under the resolution which gives effect to these changes Australia is entitled to subscribe to a maximum of about 14,500 shares. The subscription price per share is $US1,000. Australia would be required to pay 40 per cent of the subscription price at the time the shares are subscribed with the balance to be paid in three annual instalments of 20 per cent by 1 February 1990. As I indicated, the purpose in this exercise is simply to make it possible for Australia to acknowledge and act according to the responsibilities which we undertook when we became a member country of both those institutions.

More recently, the problem of world debt which faces many less developed and developing countries has attracted the attention not only of international financial institutions but also of national governments of varying levels of development throughout the world and international agencies. They have been sometimes of very crushing importance to the developing countries. Many of these developing countries have attempted to correct their external imbalance by stifling domestic activity, economic growth and employment and hence stifling domestic demand because they have become aware that it is necessary for them not only to reduce the demand which they make upon the resources of other more developed countries but also to increase their capacity to export in order to earn the foreign currency which is necessary for them to participate in turn in world commercial activities.

That problem faced by these developing countries has sometimes been of an extent which threatens to upset the balance of the world monetary system and the relationships among various countries. These developing countries have also been confronted with high levels of protectionism within the European Economic Community and North America. By 1984 the level of real growth in those developed countries which had also gone through the experience of stifling domestic demand to maintain an appropriate external balance reached almost 5 per cent. That level of real economic growth should be the target and it should prove possible to maintain it. Unfortunately, it has not been maintained.

Australia is one developed country which has experienced those same types of difficulties and problems. We are in the process of gearing back, as a result of deliberate Government policy, the rate of economic development to ensure that it is more in accord with that of overseas countries and will not have the effect of increasing Australia's domestic demand on the resources available. Hopefully it will also have the effect of releasing resources to make it possible for Australia to export more. Of course, the difficulty is that those changes are not happening quickly enough. This lies at the basis of many of the problems that we are experiencing at present. It is not only developing countries in connection with their international financial obligations which have been in difficulties as a result of protectionism in Europe and North America, but also countries such as Australia which depend almost exclusively and increasingly on the large bulk commodity items-raw materials, minerals, energy resources and primary products such as wheat, wool, meat and sugar.

Developed countries should be major markets and should assist in the export capacity of developed and developing countries to protect their own industries. It is interesting to note that in 1984-I suppose that in 1985 the figure would have been greater and in 1986, this year, perhaps even greater again-the European Community spent $23,000m in agricultural subsidies. This type of approach, combined with what has become known as the green revolution which has made it possible for developing countries which at one time were net importers of grain and foodstuffs to become net exporters, means to a very large extent that the world at the moment has literally mountains of grain and various types of agricultural products.

From the point of view of the Economic Community and North America it may be desirable to achieve self-sufficiency but in the European Community that has meant that that bloc has become a massive holder and exporter of subsidised products, especially grain, sugar, dairy products and beef. All these forms of imbalance among the developing and developed countries and the way those imbalances have been allowed to persist without adequate responses being made available within the developed or developing countries have resulted finally in a massive transfer of wealth not from the developed countries to the developing or less developed countries but in the opposite direction. To some extent again this has been the experience of Australia. The developing countries have experienced a significant downturn in their terms of trade. They have experienced a dramatic fall in and collapse of their commodity prices with the result that non-oil commodity prices this year, for example, will fall by another 18 per cent. This follows after those very dramatic falls in bulk commodity prices throughout the world over the last couple of years.

The current account will improve for industrial countries by between $40,000m and $50,000m this year, not because of any increase in the volume of their exports but because of the reduction in the prices that they are paying for their imports of bulk commodities from an increasingly impoverished Third World-the developing and underdeveloped countries. All those terms relate to the same family of countries that are experiencing increasing and massive problems. The reduced relative demand for exports from those developing countries compared with those from developed countries has meant that the combined current account deficit of developing countries last year was about $19,000m.

From $19 billion last year this year the figure is expected to be $50 billion, so the problem continues to grow. This brings about for developing countries a massive burden of debt servicing costs, with the result that in some of those countries the cost of servicing their foreign debts is in excess of the total amount they can expect to earn from their exports. It is no lack of effort on the part of these countries to produce and it is no lack of effort on the part of these countries to sell. They are selling the same quality and quantity and they are getting significantly less. At the same time the more sophisticated manufactured and processed goods which they depend upon buying from the developed countries have experienced a comparative price rise. It is rather appalling as a result of the free operation of these international market forces that circumstances should be set in train which have the effect of redirecting massive volumes of finance, massive volumes of resources and massive volumes of debt from the most impoverished countries to the most developed and affluent countries.

There is a challenge before the international community. If it is to lay claim to any degree of international morality, the challenge lies before all countries, both as individual countries and as members of those international agencies, authorities and organisations within which they are associated and of which they are members, to face up to the realities of these circumstances and not to allow themselves to support, maintain and proclaim that the free operation of international market forces is sufficient to bring about a ready resolution to problems of that kind. Quite clearly the free operation of international market forces is not adequate and will never be adequate to bring about a resolution to difficulties of that kind. It should not be that the more affluent countries and the inhabitants of those countries find their own material welfare substantially elevated as a result of this massive transfer of resources, wealth, production and finance from less developed countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could hardly believe my ears for the last five minutes or so of the peroration of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). I have never heard such an extraordinary contradiction in my life. The reason why the underdeveloped countries have got into such trouble and have such massive debt problems is, firstly, that in a lot of cases their internal economies have not encouraged free enterprise. The countries that have encouraged market forces and free enterprise within their own countries have done better than those that have had centrally controlled economies. I think that Mr Julius Nyerere's control of Tanzania's economy over 20 years was a means of impoverishing that economy which would not have happened otherwise. Economies which have had internal arrangements which are more conducive to private investment and competitive enterprise have been more successful. That has been a reason for some of these countries not doing so well and the second reason is not the free international flow of market forces, as the honourable member said, but the protectionist policies of developed countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member has the hide to come in here and tell us that these impoverished Third World countries are in difficulty when he, as the chairman of his own Party's economics committee, put up an extraordinary plan only a few months ago for physical controls on imports. That would have a direct effect on the economics of the less developed countries. I was not going to enter into a debate on international economic forces, or the free international flow of market forces that the honourable member was talking about, but I could not let that unbelievable piffle pass unremarked.

I have much pleasure in announcing that the Opposition supports the Government in respect of the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill 1986. It gives me great pleasure on occasions to support the Government's measures, particularly when the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) is at the table, and not his boss. That is one of those nice little things that happen in this place from time to time. I will not delay the House very long, but just to make it clear what it is we are agreeing to, in August 1984 the governors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is part of the World Bank Group based in Washington, agreed to an increase in the authorised capital stock of $US7 billion. This was in parallel with an earlier action in 1983 of the International Monetary Fund, of which we are also a member, to expand the quotas for individual countries. That is a normal thing that happens. Normally the World Bank follows the IMF in increasing its capital or, in the case of the IMF, its quotas.

In September 1984 the governors also allowed members whose shareholdings had suffered a relative decline to regain their earlier relative share. Australia is in that particular position. These two resolutions of the governors allowed the Bank to expand its borrowings on world markets. The Bank had been set up to help the governments of the more advanced developing countries to borrow for productive purposes. The Bank borrows on world markets and then re-lends to these countries. Members of the IBRD are entitled but not obliged to take up the extra shares. Our total entitlement of 815 shares under the two provisions was $US98.32m, of which 91 1/4 per cent was to remain on call and 8.75 per cent, which is $US8.6m, was to be paid in. Ten per cent of that has to be paid in gold and United States dollars by 31 December 1986, which is $US0.86m from us, which we are going to pay once this Bill passes the Parliament, and the balance of $US7.74m, or $A12.29m roughly at current rates of exchange, will be paid in eight equal biennial instalments over five financial years commencing in 1986-87 at the exchange rate prevailing at the time the payments are made.

The work of the IBRD is important in the South East Asian region. We do not automatically support proposals to provide funds or capital for international bodies. The Opposition examines each of these on its merits. There are some international bodies that might be highly suspect and they are matters which are the province of my colleague the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who has conducted a policy review in these areas. In this particular area we regard the World Bank as one of the more established well-respected, useful institutions which do very useful work in developing countries, and that is why we support this particular measure. We wish we could say the same for all international institutions with which we are currently associated.

The second affiliate of the World Bank included in this Bill, the International Finance Corporation, was established in 1956 to supplement the activities of the IBRD by providing finance and investment advice to private sector investors in developing countries. It is a much smaller operation. The IBRD had loans outstanding of $US105 billion in June 1986 and the International Finance Corporation had only $US2.4 billion outstanding, but those loans, of course, are to private developers in the developing countries. In this case the governors decided in December 1985 to authorise an increase in capital of $US650m, which doubled the capital of the IFC. Australia is entitled, but not obliged, to subscribe to an additional 14,560 shares at a cost of $US14.56m, all paid in in this case, first payment of $US5.824m to be made on 1 February 1987 plus three annual instalments of $US2.972 beginning in February 1988. The Opposition is pleased to support this measure and is hopeful that the work of those two institutions will materially assist in the development of countries at a less advanced stage of development than our own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In March last year and in the year before we legislated for Australia's further contribution to the International Development Association, the IDA. It is one of the arms of the World Bank. As I pointed out last year it, unlike the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the IBRD, is the provider of soft loans ostensibly to some of the less or least developed countries we set out to help as part of our multilateral efforts to give foreign aid. In the debate last year I questioned the wisdom of granting soft loans.

SPEECH.PARA: The point needs to be stressed at the outset that because one of the international institutions in which these measures seek to increase Australia's shareholdings is the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the same doubts that I have voiced about the IDA do not necessarily apply to the IBRD. That is not to say that in the absence of vital information from the Government we should not give serious consideration to the proposals to increase Australia's shareholdings in either the IBRD or the International Finance Corporation, the IFC. First I make the point that there is no cost impact statement accompanying the explanatory memorandum. Certainly, with the resources at the Government's disposal it could have given fundamental information which, in the event, is lacking. It might be possible for me and others to project the all-up cost from figures and other information given, and only then subject to possible error because of the special provisions in the Bill as well as the vagaries of the value of the Australian dollar against the United States dollar. There is also provision for Australia to subscribe for some of its shares in gold but that alternative must be deemed highly improbable and not worth dwelling upon.

Spelling out in clear and precise terms the cost implications of all legislation is but another of the solemn undertakings given by this Government which has gone by the board. It is just another broken promise in evidence on this occasion. Although one or two Ministers are notable exceptions, it is increasingly the case that the cost of proposed legislation is, unintentionally or otherwise, being kept from honourable members and therefore from the public.

I come now to the core of the Bill as it affects the IBRD. It may be useful to note that it provides hard loans to member countries traditionally at or near commercial interest rates and on something approaching commercial terms. Where it has the need to borrow it usually borrows on commercial terms from the private capital market. Although we have been told that Australia voted to support the resolution of the International Monetary Fund which authorises an increase in capital for the IBRD, we have not been told the reasons. Why did we support the enabling IMF resolution? We are simply not told.

In the second reading speech of the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) there is mention of the aim to restore the relative shareholdings of members as well as a restatement of the objectives of both the IBRD and the IFC. However, we are not told how or why increasing our shareholdings in either institution will serve our interests. In our formal foreign aid programs we can usually claim that our contributions serve our interests in either a general or a particular way, or both. There is nothing wrong with that although particular aid is questioned from time to time. In fairness to the Minister, he has stated that it is his belief, and therefore his Government's belief, that it is in our interest to continue to support these international institutions. The reasons he gives, however, do not go to the heart of the matter, or more accurately to the causative resolutions of the IMF and our support for them. It is safe to presume that the IMF resolution to increase the authorised capital stock of the IBRD by $US7 billion was passed only after discussion about whether there should be an injection of further capital or whether it should increase borrowings instead. After all, we know that the IBRD has previously borrowed heavily to be able in turn to lend. That is, after all, consistent with normal banking practice. In fact, we are advised that from 1947 to June 1986 the IBRD had lent a grand total of $US105 billion with an original capital stock of $10 billion. We do not know-we are not told-whether the total of $10 billion capital stock has been increased since 1947 but it seems to have been sufficient to cope with, along with borrowings from world capital markets, lending totalling $US105 billion to June 1986, or perhaps alternatively loans of that amount outstanding at that date. Even the current level of IBRD loans outstanding is not ascertainable from information and data accompanying the Bill.

The Government says it is in Australia's best interests to continue its policy of support by taking up in full the increase in our capital subscription to which we are entitled under the two IMF resolutions. But is it? Might it not be more in our interests to add the $US98.32m price for a further 815 shares in IBRD to our foreign aid vote over the same extended period that is to apply to the purchase of more stock? Let no one harbour the illusion that our contributions to IBRD are not in reality another form of foreign aid; they most certainly are. That being the case, it should at least be considered possible that direct, identifiable aid would serve Australia's interests better than channelling funds through an international institution and thus rendering our philanthropy anonymous in the hands of the recipient country. There appears to be nothing in the case stated by the Government to show that it might have deliberated along these lines. That is very surprising when we note how the Government rationalised reducing our foreign aid vote by $136m in real terms in its most recent Budget. Incidentally, the Opposition supported the need for expenditure cuts although with some real reservations about applying them so harshly to aid for Papua New Guinea instead of other recipients.

As my distinguished colleague at the table, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has noted, at a time when tough economic decisions are needed on the domestic front, no broad area of expenditure can or should go unaffected. It is a simple fact that our longer term ability to provide forms of special assistance and support to other nations depends on our own economic well-being. Even while we freely acknowledge that, the $US8.6m we will have to pay this year for new IBRD stock might be better used in Australia's national interests if it were granted in aid to Papua New Guinea. That $US8.6m translates into $A12m or $A13m. After all, we are not likely to see the money again in my lifetime, if ever. The same goes for the balance of just under $US90m to be paid over the next five financial years. That would arguably be better spent in aid to Papua New Guinea or in the South Pacific than it will be under these arrangements.

In annexure A to the explanatory memorandum the member countries of IBRD are listed. There are 143 countries, of which Australia is but one. Alongside the name of each country is printed the number of shares for which it may subscribe. As with Australia, each country is entitled, but is not obliged, to take up a varying number of shares. Apart from losing some minute voting entitlement if others increased their holdings, there would have been no apparent disadvantage to Australia within the IBRD if we had decided not to subscribe voluntarily. So, let it be understood that there was, and is, no compulsion. We were in no way locked in. It must be also a reasonably safe bet that many of the countries listed will not accept the offer. Our entitlement to buy additional stock is the eighteenth largest of those of the 143 countries with entitlements. Among those countries with rights to buy more shares than Australia are Iran, Kuwait, Mexico, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, and that current darling of the Australian Labor Party, Sweden. Will any of those countries-or, indeed, any of the other 142 countries-participate? We simply do not know, because we are not told.

All of this brings me back to the point that we should question whether the Parliament has enough information to conclude whether the making of further contributions to the IBRD is the most effective way to channel our limited aid resources. We are talking about foreign aid. There is no apparent economic advantage to Australia and, indeed, none has been claimed or demonstrated by the Government. The charter of the IBRD is best expressed in Article 1 of its articles of agreement, which sets out:

. . . to promote private foreign investment by means of guarantees or participation in loans and other investments made by private investors; and when private capital is not available on reasonable terms to supplement these private investments.

Over the last seven years its lending has increased by 100 per cent to $US105 billion. It seems that there is not enough private capital available any longer on reasonable terms. The IBRD is therefore obliged to resort to capital raisings from member countries in a way that has not been apparent previously. Until June 1979 the major recipients of loans from this body were, in order, Brazil, Colombia, the Philippines, Yugoslavia and Mexico. At the time, those countries were ranked as either high or middle per capita income earners. They are not amongst the least developed countries and, in some cases, are competitors of unsubsidised, cost-efficient Australian commodities exports. Let not that fact be lost on anyone. IBRD development loans typically are over a period of 25 years, with the first five years a period of grace with regard to repayments of interest and principal. Of course, interest rates on loans vary according to the cost to the bank of borrowing.

Given those few facts which the Government has not deigned to recite for the basic information of honourable members, perhaps understandably some concern exists about the future policy direction of the IBRD. Some of those doubts have been flagged by the United States House Appropriations Committee investigative staff report on international financing institutions. The Committee has found numerous shortcomings in the bank's policies. Today time does not permit me to canvass those short- comings. It may not even be necessary to do that. However, there is a formidable body of thought in the United States and elsewhere that has misgivings. That does not seem to have figured very highly in the information offered by the Government. That, in itself, is not necessarily important, except as an illustration of the paucity of information we have at our disposal in doing what I regard as our important work.

One of the shortcomings in the bank's operations appears to be that it does not undertake surveillance of, or evaluate the effectiveness of, its loans in terms of its achievement of development goals. Allegations of the misuse of funds loaned by the IBRD abound, and there is at least some evidence to support a contention that the income share to the poorest 40 per cent in lesser or least developed countries has probably worsened.

The other international financial institution which will benefit from the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill is the International Finance Corporation-the IFC. Established as it was in 1956, it has amongst its objectives the following:
To further economic development by encouraging the growth of productive private enterprises in member countries, particularly in the less developed areas.
A more specialised role, as described in an annual report, is this:

. . . to mobilise private resources on commercial terms for development projects where a market-oriented approach is not only applicable but economically preferable and where they would not be undertaken in a timely or appropriate way without the Corporation's participation.

In many ways the usefulness of the IFC is less questionable than that of the other international financial institutions to which we pay court in one way or another. On the other hand, for the purposes of meaningful debate, we again suffer from a lack of information about the real need for further shares. Australia is entitled to subscribe to a further 14,560 shares at $US1,000 each. The subscription price is also payable over a period, involving a deposit of 40 per cent followed by three annual increments of 20 per cent, the final payment becoming due on 1 February 1990.

It needs to be said that the IFC is unique in the company of comparable international lending agencies. That is particularly because the IFC has the ability to make both equity and loan investments. It does not insist on recipient government guarantees on its loans, with normal maturity dates between seven and 12 years. At the most recent count, 123 nations were subscribing shareholders, of which 110 have entitlements to take up new and additional shares. Australia is but one, but it is distinguished from the majority in that it is once again a contributor and not a recipient. Australia has the eleventh highest entitlement of all the member nations to take up new capital stock in the IFC. Only one of the countries in the top 10 of proposed subscribers for new stock is in any way a recipient, as far as can be ascertained. That country is India. I have previously canvassed my views on that country's participation in the affairs of international financial institutions. I am content to refer anyone who is interested to the House of Representatives Hansard of 26 March 1985.

As one of the youngest and smallest of the financial institutions affiliated with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, the IFC does not seem to have been subjected to the same critical scrutiny. If it has, the IFC has escaped criticism of the calibre levelled at others from time to time. That is probably due as much to the fact that it has not been bureaucratised to the extent to which other international lending institutions, including the IBRD, have been. However, the most likely reason that the IFC looks better when compared with the World Bank and its other affiliates is that it is bound to observe specific commercial operational practices. That is entirely commendable. In that context, it is instructive to note that the World Bank never foresaw the international debt crisis that now exists. That defect is despite the fact that the bank spent a hefty $US50m during the 1970s on a world development model that was supposed to project international development trends. In fact, nobody at the World Bank even programmed debt figures into the model until 1981. It transpired during the 1970s that many governments came to believe that the World Bank and its affiliates needed them as borrowers more than they needed the bank as the lender. The bank probably deserved that reaction from its customers because it seemed to bust a boiler in trying to peddle its wares.

Because the coalition does not oppose this legislation, my remarks are intended to introduce the need for caution in continuing to subscribe our taxpayers' funds to institutions, the functions and efficacy of which may be outmoded. In particular, any Commonwealth government of the day should be ever alert to the possibility that money which is essentially part of our foreign aid effort might be better used. There must be always at least the possibility that we would be better off directing our humanitarian aid efforts bilaterally and pulling out of multilateral institutions where our interests may have to be sacrificed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) made some important points in his contribution but, unfortunately, he appeared to draw the wrong conclusion. He seemed to draw the conclusion that even though the Opposition will not oppose the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill he, personally, would like to see a re-evaluation of the whole issue of the contributions of Australia to the World Bank process. The problem with that is that it does not focus on what is the real difficulty. The real difficulty is that the World Bank needs to be restructured and its goals need to be reconsidered. However, one does not achieve that process, one does not achieve that situation, by withdrawing Australia from the World Bank process. What one has to do if one really wants to achieve a redirection of the activities of the World Bank is to get Australia and other nations involved in achieving that redirection.

SPEECH.PARA: Why do I say that this is an important matter? It is an important matter because at the present time a major crisis is occurring in relation to the foreign debt of many Third World developing nations. There is an enormous financial crisis in these nations. Just to illustrate the point, a lot has been said about the emergency aid which was raised by Bob Geldof and many other people for Africa. One of the things that are not known, one of the things that have not been advertised, is that in the last 12 months Africa paid out four times as much money in debt repayments as it received in emergency aid. In other words, the debt burden of the African nations has crippled their capacity to use emergency aid effectively, to use that aid to rebuild Africa and, hopefully, to achieve a situation in which the starvation problem can be resolved. When we are faced with facts of that kind or when we are faced with facts about the crippling debt burden of Latin American countries or certain Asian countries there is a responsibility for the World Bank and other international organisations, such as the International Monetary Fund, to look sympathetically at the problem.

The honourable member for Curtin mentioned that the World Bank is not achieving its goals at the present time. If that is the case what we need to do is ask: How can the World Bank and the IMF restructure their operations so that we can deal sympathetically with the problems of Third World nations? It is no good trying to pretend that a myth exists. Unfortunately, we have the rescheduling of debts, the further rescheduling of debts, a continual process of rescheduling of debts, but we have no recognition of the fact that these countries cannot pay even the interest on their debts. In that situation what is required is for us to bite the bullet and to consider the possibility of writing off the debts of the poorest nations. That is an important matter. The United Nations has tried to get something going along this path but it is still having difficulties because people fail to accept responsibility for the fact that the loans were made under terms and conditions which made it virtually impossible for the nations to repay their debts.

We should not look at the matter in purely economic and financial terms; we have to look at it in human terms. In human terms it is an absolute tragedy for the Third World that this situation is continuing. The Government ought to continue to participate-as this Bill requires-in the World Bank process and to see whether we can get a more sympathetic hearing for the problems of the so-called south, the underdeveloped world. We hear a lot about the debate between the East and the West but we hear very little about the problems of the underdeveloped world and the massive poverty that exists there. There is not enough debate and discussion about this matter in the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a big threat to peace as well.

—As the honourable member mentions, many peace problems with which we are concerned-often we see them in terms of East and West-often stem from the extraordinary poverty which exists in many Third World countries, and there is no question about that. The world economy is going through a very serious transition process at the moment-there is no doubt about it-but what is happening? Selfishness has become the major consideration and we are reaching a situation in which the nations which are in a position to increase and to expand their economies, for example, Japan, West Germany and certain other European countries which could be importing more from the Third World and, incidentally, from Australia, are failing to do so. Why are they failing to do so? It is because they have a foolish policy, a beggar thy neighbour policy. They are refusing to expand their economies even though their currencies are overvalued, even though they have domestic surpluses and even though their people would increase their standards of living if greater imports and greater expansion of their economies were allowed. This is an extraordinarily selfish attitude on the part of the governments of Japan, West Germany and certain other European countries. We have to put pressure on those nations that are doing well, nations that can afford expansion, nations that can afford to assist the Third World through greater imports and greater capital investment. We are not reaching that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is extraordinary when nations which have a very highly overvalued currency and such a potential for much greater growth in their domestic economies simply refuse to expand their economies and to assist their own people in improving their standards of living. Historically some nations have felt threatened about any policy of substantial growth. However, the Japanese economy can afford substantial expansion and if it does not expand and other economies do not expand the whole world economy will be in crisis. The nations that will feel this burden will be the underdeveloped and Third World nations.

In addition, the United States economy has problems. The United States economy was supposed to expand but it failed to do so. All the predictions of the pick-up in the United States economy in the last year have not come true and that has had a very severe impact. We have seen the impact in Australia, with the imposition of very tough protection measures in the United States against our primary products-wheat and sugar. We will see a situation whereby the United States will subsidise its produce and not merely put up protective barriers against our produce. If it is true that the whole world economy is moving towards an increasingly protectionist position, as is happening with the European bloc, the Asian bloc and the United States, what will happen to the poorest nations? What will happen to the developing South? That is the crucial issue which we, the World Bank, the IMF and other bodies need to face and we need to talk more about these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, we are debating the International Financial Institutions (Share Increases) Bill which seeks to increase Australia's contributions to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was referring to some of the extremely serious problems of the Third World and the fact that there need to be substantial changes in the structure of the international finance system and, indeed, in the international trading system if we are to deal with the problems of the Third World and overcome the extreme problems of poverty which developing nations currently face. I referred, of course, to the huge debt repayments which these nations have to make and the fact that often they cannot even generate enough income to pay their interest bill on those debts. So we have the extraordinary situation where these nations are always going backwards, and they are going backwards at a very rapid pace.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons for this situation is the fact that for many years the international financial system has been structured so as to benefit the most powerful nations and the most wealthy nations. These nations have been able to influence currency values through the international financial system. They have been able to impose an economic value system which benefits especially the United States of America, Western Europe and Japan. In that kind of context we have had a situation in which the international monetary system is fundamentally mistaken and needs to be changed. That is a problem that the world, especially the so-called South or the poor world countries, faces.

Of course, any attempt to reform the international monetary system, any attempt to reform the whole system of existing exchange values between countries, is itself confronted with resistance from the powerful group of so-called 10 nations which control the international monetary system. That is an extremely sad situation because in fact it is a shortsighted perception of their self-interest. If the situation continues as it is at present we will see increasing desperation on the part of the Third World nations which will manifest itself in a collapse of much of the world monetary and banking systems.

Let us not kid ourselves about how serious this problem is. Of course, every time there has been a major crisis there has been a rescheduling of the debts of nations such as Mexico, Argentina and the Philippines. But we cannot continue along that path because eventually we will have a chaotic situation in respect of the whole meaning of money and the financial system. I urge the Government to play whatever role it possibly can in international forums to ensure that Australia takes a progressive and sympathetic view of the plight of developing nations. That is not only something that needs to be said in relation to the interests of those nations; it is also something that needs to be said in relation to our interests because we are in the peculiar positions that we share some of the interests of Third World nations. We share their concern about low commodity prices which are being paid by the so-called First World. We share their concern that prices of commodities have been forced down as a result of all kinds of conspiracies arranged by First World nations-the richer nations of the world. Those conspiracies have worked not only against the poor developing nations but also against Australia. We have heard a lot in this place about the deterioration of Australia's terms of trade. But we have not had much discussion about the causes of that phenomenon. The cause is the capacity of a small group of powerful industrialised nations to impose increasingly reduced prices for natural resources on which much of the developing world depends.

We should not be providing a bit of aid here and a bit of aid there to developing countries. What we need to do is actively engage the countries of the Third World in such areas as industrialisation, production and the generation of value. We need to go out there and involve them in this process. We also need to open these countries up as markets for manufactured products, both products that they can manufacture themselves and products that are manufactured by other nations. If we do that we will be in a position to achieve a much better situation than the current crisis we face. Indeed, the current crisis is not only a crisis, as I said, of the financial system but increasingly it is a crisis in the trading system. World trade is being reduced because of increased protectionism, because countries are forming into blocs such as the European Economic Community. Countries are forming into blocs in Asia. They are also forming into blocs or working together in northern America. We are finding increasingly that the Australian nation is being cut out of those blocs. But we are not the only ones. Many nations poorer than Australia are also being cut out of this system and they are, therefore, becoming increasingly desperate.

I would warn that this is not just an economic or financial matter. This is a matter which has repercussions in terms of world peace because if these nations become more desperate and if they become more impoverished there is the possibility that we will get increasing conflict between one Third World nation and another, and between nations of the Third World and nations of the First World. That conflict could lead to super-power conflict and have very serious repercussions for world peace. So I would urge the Government to look at not merely the support it has given the World Bank but, as I have already said, that it participates actively in the processes of the World Bank to ensure that the Bank's policies are humanitarian, that it looks sympathetically at the problems of the Third World and that those problems are resolved through genuine investment and genuine growth in Third World economies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill has become a wide-ranging discussion about international economic trade matters, including the world's financial system, and I welcome that. The legislation comes before the House at a time of a trade war between the United States of America on the one hand, and the European bloc on the other-the countries of the European Economic Community. This Bill provides for Australia to increase capital funds to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation. The major activity of the bank is to provide loans to developing member countries. These developing member countries are now the victims of the trade war between the United States on the one hand and Europe on the other.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is also caught in this trade war. Our major traditional agricultural exports are under threat. I believe the situation will deteriorate. It can only become worse and it will become an ever more massive problem than it already is for Australia. There is little we can do directly in Europe but I believe the time has come for a full frontal diplomatic and political campaign to be mounted and directed at Europe's policy makers, especially the members of the parliaments of the individual countries that make up the Common Market as well as the European Parliament itself. Deficits are increasing in many Third World and lesser developed countries as well as in Australia and the United States of America; they are apparently out of control. The two major problems in the United States are its trading and government deficits, and these two problems affect world trade and currency values. Trade and the resulting exchange rate effects are now a vitally imperative factor in international relations. Trade wars affect relations between countries. The effect on particular countries causes severe balance of trade problems and consequential balance of payments problems. These have a consequent effect on the value of currencies of particular countries.

The Bretton Woods agreement on fixed exchange rates has broken down under these large imbalances created by the current situation in world trade. The imbalances in various countries' trade and capital flows are vitally affected by the trade wars. The effect on Third World and lesser developed countries is devastating. The dramatic falls in commodity prices have devastated their economies. The Third World producers, the lesser developed countries, have no chance to produce because, on the one hand, they are locked out of markets by the European Community and, on the other hand, products are dumped on their former customers' market, and Australia is also in that situation. So the less developed countries have no chance to sell products on the world markets and they are locked into a cycle of decline. As I have stated, the Australian economy is also affected and is in a state of decline. We are facing the greatest challenge of having to respond to a changed world. Our standard of living continues to fall. We may well ultimately be a recipient of a loan from these institutions if things continue as they are but this evening we are debating whether we should contribute capital to them.

The countries of the European Community and the United States will regard our problems as irrelevant to their trading positions. I have already talked about my pessimism of Europe opening up. I think its surpluses will grow and it will become more isolationist. I also think there is a possibility that it will have the same common interest in relation to world trade as does the Soviet Union. On the other hand, the United States will fight this by dumping products on world markets, including traditional Australian markets and on the markets of the lesser developed countries. That is a challenge for the Third World and a challenge for Australia. Our challenge is one that we should be able to meet because we live in one of the most dynamic trading regions of the world, but we are failing to take advantage of it.

We should adopt a `friends of the Pacific' approach. We should focus our attention on the Pacific and Asia. The area encompassing the western Pacific region, north and South East Asia and Australasia is the key to our trading future. However, it is frightening that we are becoming a less and less important trader in our immediate region. Our share of trade in the Western Pacific region is actually falling. This is dramatic and of concern because it is the most dynamic trading centre of the world. The countries of this region are enjoying enormous growth. Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan are all enjoying enormous growth and relatively good free trading opportunities. We must not fail in the challenge; we must take up the opportunities. We need to be much more outward looking. We need to restructure our manufacturing industry. We need to go through a process of great structural change. We need to encourage the growth of the tourist industry in Australia, which has developed and which is maturing but which still has to be expanded. It has a great potential to be one of the economic saviours of the country.

As the world trade crisis-which is addressed by the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill-deteriorates at the same time as these international banking institutions and organisations are raising capital and we are contributing to long term loans to developing Third World countries, and at the same time as the terms of trade for the Third World nations and for many countries, such as Australia, are deteriorating, there is a new international financial revolution taking place in many parts of the Western World. It is taking place in the most important Western economies. Financial deregulation is the name of the game. It is providing opportunities for growth and opportunities for countries to participate in the growth of the financial services sector, which is in itself dynamic.

One of the tests of any Third World economy, indeed of any economy in regard to free trade and the encouragement of growth, is whether that economy prohibits foreign bank entry. The prohibition of foreign bank entry is one of the most blatant financial barriers. It is only in recent years that Australia has abandoned its prohibition on foreign bank entry but even now it is restrictive because only 16 banks are licensed to operate in Australia. However, I am pleased that Australia has entered the deregulated financial world and prohibitions of bank entry in the Western economy are becoming rarer. But bans do exist. They exist in most of the Third World countries which will be granted loans from the bank which is receiving capital as a result of this legislation being passed. The Soviet bloc of course is outside the free flow of bank entry and financial services. Most developing nations, except the most newly industrialised ones of Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan, I regret still have barriers to bank entry. Developing countries are blind to the fact that the entry of foreign banks and financial deregulation would help private sector investment in their economies. That is one of the matters that have not been raised in the debate this evening.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), used very interesting language and said that the Third World had to participate in the process with the World Bank. I would say that is right if the Third World realised that it is only by the development of free market economies, by recognising the importance of the market-place in those economies and by recognising that international trade and finance are linked and that we need to have foreign bank entry that these countries can help themselves and can have economic growth and a future. I believe that is more important than the sorts of loans that are being discussed as a result of this legislation. I am not decrying those loans. I believe the World Bank and the financial institutions, which are the subject of this legislation, are very important. But the Third World and the lesser developed countries must realise that they must develop free market economies in order to have growth. The deregulation of financial markets is important if world trade and growth is to continue.

In the time available to me this evening I would like to look at another aspect of international trade. I have talked about Australia having to take advantage of living in the Western Pacific region. We are really a platform in the western Pacific for north and South East Asia. As I said, we are failing to take advantage of this. I think we have to develop a greater financial and trading strategy. We need to understand that while the trade war continues-as I said the conditions continue to get worse between Europe on the one hand and the United States on the other-Japan and Germany, which are growth economies, and other European economies still invest their trade surpluses in the United States because the United States dollar is the world reserve currency. This may not continue to be the case. The United States is currently putting pressure on West Germany and Japan to stimulate their economies and to lower their interest rates so that they will hopefully import, when their economies are so stimulated, from the United States. I am a little pessimistic about that and think it is a little too simplistic and is unlikely to work because the United States has not been a long term traditional market for Europe. West Germany and Japan have not been long term traditional markets for United States manufacturers. That has to be taken into account when looking at the situation.

I also note in passing that there has been a recent accord between the United States and Japan on the value of currency. Japan is a key to this region of the world. It is a key to the health, growth and the opening up of world trade. Australia has good trading relations and good relations generally with Japan. We have a responsibility to encourage Japan to be outward looking, to take imports, to lift barriers to imports and, over and above that, to encourage it to invest in Latin America. As I have said, the international financial strategy of the United States Government is to try to get Japan and West Germany to stimulate their economies to take more United States imports. That is likely to fail. When one looks at the historical position of United States in world trade one sees that the most important sectors for United States exports have been Canada-which has, again, turned inward looking and is engaging in its own trade war with the US-and South America which was a key market for United States exports and a healthy United States economy.

Having painted that picture, I am brought back to Japan. As I said, we need to encourage Japan to be outward looking in terms of world trade, but we need to encourage the Japanese to invest their trade surpluses around the world, particularly in Latin America. If Japan invests its surpluses in Latin America it will create growth in South America, which will help the United States economy by a demand for goods because the United States is looked to as a traditional supplier, and it will also help the United States banking system which is under incredible pressure as a result of sovereign South American debt. Japan is a key and Australia has a very important role to play in explaining this to Japan and in encouraging it to invest its surpluses in Latin and South America.

Australia has its own difficulties. I mentioned these-to encourage manufacturing industry to restructure. We need to encourage tourism in particular. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) must not be complacent. He has even more work to do in the future. I refer to Australia taking advantage of participating in the financial revolution that is occurring around the world and the expanded financial services sector that is occurring as a result of financial deregulation in many Western countries. I read recently an interesting paper by Mr N. R. Clark, who is the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank Ltd, on the impact of international banking on competitiveness. A summary of that states:
This paper argues that Australian banks are operating in an environment of rapid change-
that is true-
with explosive changes in international financial markets-
that is true-
driven by deregulation, emerging communications and technologies.
Mr Clark goes on:
. . . if the banks in Australia are to obtain the full benefits of deregulation and the capacity to compete with global banks-
that is important-
tax policies and the attitude of bank supervisors must not hinder our progress.

That is a summary of his words. I will not deal with his comments on the attitude of bank supervisors as it is not relevant to this debate-that goes to prudential deregulation of banking-but I will go to the comments he makes about the capacity to compete with global banks. I think it is very important to note that such an important Australian banker as Mr Clark makes this point:
Already Australia's taxation processes and currency are inimical to our off-shore competitive prospects.

He points out that we still have a foreign tax credit system which threatens to inhibit our international competitiveness and an off-shore banking market will not get off the ground if it is taxed at 49 per cent compared to other markets at 10 per cent. So here we have the opportunity to participate in the financial services revolution that is going on in the world. Even more importantly we have the opportunity to participate in the western Pacific region of the world at a time when we are in the same time zone approximately as Hong Kong and Singapore, when the world is moving to 24-hour round the clock trading. We must not pass up the opportunity to participate in that expansion. We must not export the opportunity to participate in an off-shore currency and banking market by continuing with the current policy of taxing off-shore banking operations at 49 per cent. This Government needs, and this country needs to develop, policies that recognise that there are different tax regimes in the world. If Australian companies are to participate, particularly in the financial services sector, we have to create legitimate off-shore banking market units that are taxed at the same rate as their competitors.

Financial deregulation and the world's financial revolution give us great opportunities. One such opportunity which I have talked about is the participation in the off-shore banking markets. We have the opportunity to participate in the financial growth of the western Pacific region. We must no pass up this opportunity; we must act, otherwise we will continue to become a Third World country. We will be donating capital to institutions which will be lending to Third World countries. We may end up borrowing back from ourselves if we are not careful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Financial Institution (Share Increase) Bill, which authorises increases in Australia's contributions by way of further subscription to shares to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation, raises the whole issue of Australia's international aid and development assistance program of which this is a part. Indeed, it raises the issues of the whole world's development assistance program. Australia's program took something of a beating from the Hawke Government in the last Budget. The total aid provision is $960.5m. Last year the provision was $1,031m so there has been a cut of 7 per cent in money terms, or some 12.8 per cent in real terms, that is, allowing for inflation. As a percentage of the gross national product, the 1986-87 provision is 0.39 per cent, the lowest for 20 years, if not ever, for this country. It was 0.46 per cent last year and over 0.5 per cent-half of one per cent-the year before. Australia did all but touch 0.6 per cent in the late 1960s. There has been a very serious deterioration in the aid and development assistance effort looked at in that way. As is well known, the target figure of the United Nations is 0.7 per cent. Australia is committed to achieving that figure but it has a long way to go. True, the average aid effort of the developed countries in 1985 was 0.35 per cent of their gross national product collectively. So at least our figure is above that.

SPEECH.PARA: In being critical of the Hawke Government's aid provision, I am aware that there is far from universal support in the electorate for a large overseas aid effort by this country. Quite often we come up against a view in the electorate that charity begins at home, that there are more important priorities just down the road, that there is much to be done for our own poor and underprivileged in education, health, housing and so on. This view is perhaps reinforced in more recent times by the perception that the extent of the difficulties of developing countries has somehow diminished in recent years. That perception stems from the undoubted fact that the level of food production and the extent of food self-sufficiency have improved significantly in many developing countries, for example, in India-although certainly not in the developing countries of Africa. Some developing countries have become food exporters.

Nevertheless, developing countries as a whole continue to be net importers of food. The basic economic factor is that, whereas industrial countries subsidise their farmers and, as a result, produce massive food surpluses, most developing countries tax their farmers in one form or another. Developing countries then are, as a whole, net importers of food; the extent of chronic malnutrition in developing countries is vast; and there are other dimensions of poverty. One thinks of health, infant mortality rates and so on. The impact of the so-called debt crisis, which the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) referred to, which erupted in 1982, has been devastating for the more heavily indebted countries, such as Argentina, Brazil, Mexico and so on.

We have had a taste of what it is like here, with our gross overseas debt, of Third World proportions under the policies of the Hawke Government, recently attaining the order of $90 billion. In 1985 Brazil's overseas debt was $107 billion and Mexico's overseas debt was $109 billion. There is no escaping the necessity and inevitability of tightening belts and of lower standards of living until we can adjust. That is what this country has to face.

As net financial flows to the heavily indebted Third World countries contracted and turned negative, along with falls in commodity prices, investment in most of those countries fell. Some developing countries have seen an absolute contraction in their base of productive capital. The real gross domestic product of 17 major heavily indebted countries fell by an average of 0.3 per cent a year from 1981 to 1985. Real incomes fell even faster, so millions of poor people in those countries have become poorer still, putting great political strain on the governments of those countries.

So, contrary to the view that the problem has diminished, there is a tremendous problem in the Third World, the so-called South. Overall, countries such as Australia have an important obligation and, indeed, a national interest in aid and developing programs. In humanitarian terms, that begins with the injunction of Christ that `of those to whom much is given much will be expected'? As has been stated by other speakers, it is important that the international aid and development effort is also significant in respect of preserving world peace. As former American President Carter said, one cannot have a peaceful world one-third rich and two-thirds hungry. The fact is that the circumstances of underdevelopment, the poverty of the South vis-a-vis the relatively rich North, exacerbated in many cases by great power interventions, are a potential source of conflict with the possibility-almost as great as that inherent in the tensions between East and West-of escalating to a world conflict.

What is at stake are not only humanitarian concerns, but no less an objective than world peace. There is the further factor of the mutual economic interest of both the donor countries and the recipient countries, the developing countries. There is a great and increasing mutual dependence between the developed and the developing countries which means that it is in our straight out, long term economic interest to mount a significant development and aid effort. I referred a while ago to the problem of Third World debt and the plight of indebted countries. During the deep world recession of 1980-82 there can be little doubt that had it not been for the massive deficit financed spending, so to speak, of the developing world during that period-in this way the developing countries provide a large market for the products of developed countries, just as the developed countries provide markets for the developing countries; there is a mutual interdependence-the extent of the decline in world economic activity would have been greater and the level of unemployment in the developed countries, which was very significant, would have been higher still. So it was the purchasing by the developing world-admittedly financed by massive borrowing-which held up world economic activity to the extent that it was held up during that period.

That points to the importance of making a rational, concerted effort to cope with the debt situation-an internationally co-ordinated effort to stretch out the debt of the developing countries and to reduce interest rates on their borrowings. I have no illusions but that the ultimate cost of that will be borne by Western taxpayers as that operation is put into effect and bank debts are taken over as government bonds and so on. It would amount to an additional involuntary transfer to the less developed countries. I believe that in the long run these transfers have to be vastly increased on what is their present level, so I do not necessarily disapprove of such an additional transfer. Again I stress that there is a good deal of mutual benefit in the procedure. It is not just a soft-headed, charitable outlook to say that eventually we will have to get down to the job of dealing with the problem, substantially in terms of so-called `debt forgiveness'.

I am appealing to the Australian electorate to support the Parliament, which, in effect, is supporting this measure. We need political support in this area. The North-South imbalance is a problem of quite massive proportions. It can be tackled only by governments, major institutions or large scale private sector activity in terms of the large scale level of lending which we have seen in recent years-plus the right policies in the countries concerned. I stress that point, and in so doing I do not in any way belittle the contributions in this area by voluntary organisations, such as World Vision, the Freedom from Hunger Campaign-

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent organisation.

—An excellent organisation, as my colleague says. There is also the Maranatha Trust, an organisation I am proud to be associated with, and so on. They all do great work. They are also of the utmost importance in the context of the need to mobilise political opinion in this country in support of Australia's official aid effort. As I said, the magnitude of attempting to rectify the imbalance between the relatively rich North and the poor South is such that only governments and large scale commercial activity can come up with the resources on the necessary scale. It is good to see the extent of bipartisan support for this measure tonight as part of the country's aid and development effort.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill proposes support for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation which are effective and efficient institutions, by and large, for the provision of development aid. If aid is to be given it has to be the right sort of help. If money is spent to build four-lane highway through a jungle joining nowhere to nowhere, as has happened, aid or development assistance can become a joke. The bureaucrats who administer it cannot be trusted, and so the attitude develops that it is better not to give the aid at all. It is increasingly true in the activities of the institutions we are supporting today that aid and development money is given in ways that can help private enterprise. And there is an increasing tendency in the sort of policy discussions that go along with aid negotiations to focus increasingly on the need for free market prices, trade liberalisation and a friendly commercial environment for foreign companies and investors-which are important in the basic strengthening of the countries private sectors.

The aid has to be in the right form and it also has to go in the right directions. It is entirely proper for the Australian aid and development effort to focus particularly on developing countries in our neighbourhood and to be framed with Australian economic and political interests firmly in sight. The Government has seen fit to cut back the program this year, as I have already said. Whether the reallocation of funds will best serve our trading and general standing in the Asia-Pacific region is a question. It was explored by my colleague the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). For example, it is true that aid to the South Pacific region was cut by 9 per cent to $54m in the last Budget. Within a total appropriation of nearly $1 billion, as I said earlier, the case for a substantially higher allocation to the newly emergent island nations of the Pacific is very strong, particularly in the face of United States reluctance to accede to the request by 11 South Pacific nations for an annual $20m for tuna fishing rights, and on the other hand the expanding Soviet presence and specific initiatives in the region.

Here there is a great opportunity. The human and political usefulness of development and educational aid to these small nations in the South Pacific is enormous. It compares more than favourably with the hardly visible useful results from the support we give to a whole range of United Nations agencies.

I conclude by referring to a point raised by the honourable member for Calwell, who talked of East-West rivalry and the massive expenditure on armaments. That has a fairly direct impact on development aid. But while a very large proportion of total military spending is by the super-powers, it is not confined to them. The complexity, challenge and utter frustration in this whole area before the House tonight is quite graphically underlined by the statistics of the non-oil developing countries which are generally the poorest. They put more money into military spending than education, health and welfare put together. That latter sum, coincidentally, is about equal to their development aid. I repeat that this underlines the complexity and frustration of this matter but it is not easy to say what should be done.

It would be nice to have a formula which linked the receipt of aid and development assistance with a decrease in spending on arms in those countries. The Germans tried something like that a few years back in some Latin American countries. But by and large that is pretty Utopian-something of a dream world. What is important is that this apparently perverse outcome to which I referred should not lead us to curtail the sorts of activities, actions, and the provision of funds that we are debating tonight. We certainly have to work in that direction. Simultaneously we have to work in the direction of negotiation for arms control and disarmament. We have to continue with great purpose on both these fronts in the interests of the adequate development of the world economy, and the preservation of world peace.
