—I am talking about the Bills that are here now.

—I am coming to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1986. If the honourable member for Macarthur will wait a moment, I am coming to the Bill and I will come to it in full measure. It is perfectly legitimate for the Opposition to point out that in the last election the honourable member for Macarthur stood behind the Prime Minister in his promise under the trilogy to maintain taxation within 25 per cent of our national product; it is now 25.5 per cent. The honourable member for Macarthur bears with the Prime Minister the burden of that broken promise. The cost of that is $1,400m in additional taxation revenues, which is, as an example, twice the amount of money that the fringe benefits tax is expected to bring in in a full year. That is a measure of the failure of this Government to meet its promises and it is a measure of its profligacy with the money of ordinary citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go to the various provisions of this Bill. I will deal with some of them fairly quickly because we have a number of Bills taken together. The first one I want to touch on briefly is the change in provisional tax that applies to partnerships and trusts. Partnerships and trusts were able to vary the pattern of their distribution of benefits to partners or beneficiaries to reduce their provisional tax payable in alternate years. They could vary the pattern of distribution from one year to another, but this is restricted under the proposed legislation. This is all very well. The intention of the provision is to prevent changes in the distribution of benefits from partnerships or trusts in order to minimise taxation, and it is a legitimate objective of the Government to do that. The only question I have in this case is what is the retrospective nature of this provision because the timing of it is such that a number of arrangements would have already been made which will be affected by this provision. People will not have time to rearrange their affairs before this provision comes into effect and therefore there is, indeed, a retrospective element in this particular change.

I draw attention to that and I ask the Minister whether or not the Government has considered the fact that various arrangements made under partnerships or trusts that were made before the announcements might be affected in a retrospective way by this and whether the Government has any intention of dealing with that situation.

The next matter I come to is changes in the capital gains tax. The capital gains tax is one of the major measures within the statement of so-called reforms made by the Treasurer in September last year. It is a measure which has caused considerable controversy. It is a measure which, although announced on 19 September last year, was not introduced into the House until May. When it was introduced I drew to the attention of the House that there was no explanatory memorandum made available by the Treasurer on the Thursday night the Bill was introduced. I managed to get a draft copy of the explanatory memorandum on the Sunday following the Thursday night on which the Bill was introduced. From memory, it had to be debated on the Tuesday or Wednesday and it was not until the summing-up of the debate by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford)-I point out that the Treasurer did not deign to come into the House to reply-that the explanatory memorandum was made generally available to members.

For a measure which encompassed 103 pages of legislation, an explanatory memorandum which was 155 pages when it ultimately appeared, a booklet subsequently produced for advice to taxpayers of 65 pages and tax rulings and Press releases amounting to some 19 pages it was an absolute scandal that, firstly, after eight months the Treasurer was not able to produce an explanatory memorandum to the House for proper debate in this House, and that, secondly, he did not deign to come into the House to answer the various questions raised by the Opposition about the capital gains tax and also that he refused point blank to answer any questions in the House about it. I remind honourable members that on 15 October 1986 in Hansard at page 2033 the Treasurer said:
. . . we will answer the questions when the Opposition decides to support the tax.
In answer to a question from my friend the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), he went on to say:
When the Opposition comes to the point of tax decency we will answer all its questions.

The Treasurer had also refused the Opposition briefings on these tax matters until I raised in the House the fact that these briefings had been denied, which was against previous practice. I can only repeat in the House tonight that the arrogance of the Treasurer and his view about the democratic proceedings of this House are really unparalleled in the history of Treasurers of this country. No previous Treasurer has treated this House with such contempt. It is just unbelievable that he would deny the Opposition briefings by officers of the Australian Taxation Office on Bills until challenged publicly in the House, and then give most unsatisfactory briefings at times which were inconvenient. It is most extraordinary that he would refuse to answer questions in the House on the grounds that the Opposition did not support the measure, yet all these things are recorded in Hansard. If he has managed to get away with this for so long it is only because he has managed to mesmerise a whole lot of people in the community up to a point, but he certainly will get his comeuppance in these matters.

I give an undertaking to this House that when I take over that particular role after the next election I will not behave in that manner. I will behave in a decent manner and I will actually be very ready indeed to have members of the Opposition briefed on taxation measures and be prepared, within the limits of what information is available to me at the time, to give adequate and satisfactory answers to the House. The predominance of this Parliament in the legislative process should not be challenged and it is quite impossible and improper that the Treasurer should behave in that particular way.

In this particular matter he said for many months that the capital gains tax, like the fringe benefits tax, was perfect, but everybody in the community knew that it was not. For months people were subject to its provisions without knowing even what its provisions were. Indeed, some people actually paid capital gains tax before the Bill had been brought in. The Bill applied from 19 September last year but it was not brought into the Parliament until May this year, so a number of people had incurred taxation liabilities in the intervening period without knowing the detail of the legislation. Whenever the Treasurer deigned to partly answer a question on this matter, he said: `Well, it was clear in my statement of 19 September'. It was anything but clear. Of course, we realised that when in May we got this Bill of 103 pages of immense complexity. It was left to a businessman to pick out one of the most extraordinary bungles in the whole measure. In an article in the Australian of 16 July 1986 is a reference to the problem of options issued by companies. I quote from an article by Bryan Frith in the Australian of that date, in which he said:
Australia's leading companies face an unexpected tax bill of almost $100m because of a bungle in the drafting of the capital gains tax on option issues.
Capital raisings were intended to be exempt from the tax. But the drafting of the legislation stated only that the issue of shares by companies would be exempt.
It did not extend to cover capital raised by securities other than shares, such as options.
CSR Ltd's recent decision to call off its proposed $62 1/2m options issue because of the capital gains tax legislation has turned out to be only the tip of the iceberg.

More than 20 companies have already made options issues since last September when a capital gains tax was foreshadowed. The amounts raised total almost $200m which, on a 49 per cent tax rate, would give the companies a tax bill of almost $100m.

I interpose here that the Treasurer estimated that this tax would raise only $25m after five years. Yet with the actual legislation as drafted the Government would have raised $100m within a few months. The article continued:
This is an unintended effect-
I give Mr Frith credit for use of the word `unintended' well before the Prime Minister used it in relation to the fringe benefits tax-
of the recently enacted capital gains tax legislation. When the tax was foreshadowed it was estimated that it would raise only $5m in the first year, rising to $25m after five years.
The article went on:
The problem was discovered by Mr Strauss-
that is, Mr Strauss of Bridge Oil Ltd-

when he was pouring over the Act. He noted the reference to shares only and inquired of his company's solicitors if that could mean options would not be exempt and therefore liable for capital gains tax.
Bridge recently raised $23.26m through an issue of 155.1 million options at 15c each.

The advice he received was that the option right to take up shares at a specified price would be regarded under the legislation as a `deemed asset' and the issue of the options would trigger a sale of that asset.

After eight months of preparation of this legislation it was found by Mr Strauss, a businessman, that there was a total bungle in this matter and an unintended consequence had been written into the Act which meant that it would have raised almost $100m in one year versus $5m in the first year and $25m after five years. The Bill we are dealing with tonight seeks to correct this anomaly or unintended consequence.

I wish to raise another matter. I ask the Treasurer to reply if he has the slightest interest in the Bill and manages to come in at the end of the debate or sends the Minister Assisting the Treasurer in to reply or sends a message via the honourable member for Parramatta, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). I refer to clause 31, which extends the operation of the capital gains tax vis-a-vis joint tenants so that for a surviving proprietor the effective date of acquisition by the survivor of the deceased's share is the date of acquisition by the deceased and under the current Act the date of acquisition is the date of death of the deceased joint tenant. I want some advice from the Treasurer as to why that change is being made and whether it disadvantages the people involved in such a transaction. I look forward to some explanation of that.

I now go on to the introduction of a $200 charge on people who wish to query their tax returns. At the moment, before this legislation goes through, it costs $2 to lodge an appeal against a decision by the Commissioner of Taxation. Under this piece of legislation a filing fee of $200 will be required for applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for appeals which would previously have gone to the Taxation boards of review at a cost of $2. This is an example of the Government being taken in by the senior boardroom mentality of the Treasurer. The recommendation obviously has been made to reduce very severely the number of appeals. Certainly this measure has raised a storm of objections from the Australian Taxpayers Association, the various tax institutes, chartered accountants representing people in these matters and the general public. It is pretty unusual to get an increase of a charge multiplying the original charge by 100.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even for this Government.

—It is fairly unusual even in legislation by this Government. This $200 fee-notwithstanding that it is refundable in cases in which the appeal is successful-obviously represents a clear disincentive for small taxpayers, who must make a $200 punt for a doubtful small return. Taxpayers may have to wait for up to three years before their appeal is concluded and the $200 fee is refunded. It is clear that the intention in imposing the fee is to discourage taxpayers from using the appeal process to delay the payment of tax. However, given that there might be some valid reason for that, the fee of $200 is clearly excessive. We have received a number of representations on this matter, as no doubt have Government members. I see that the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) is gearing himself for the debate. I would be interested to hear the honourable member defend the one hundred-fold increase in the charge.
—He will do it brilliantly.
—The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism says that he will do it well and he associates himself with the defence of the $200 fee.
—Absolutely.
—Let us see what he says after I have had a few further things to say.
—I wonder whether he will defend taxing people's family homes as well.

—He obviously will because he supports the Government's capital gains tax, which does tax people's family homes. Indeed, if anybody in the community wants to know exactly how the family home will be taxed under the capital gains tax he should send a letter to the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who will give him a very clear indication by return post as to in which circumstances the family home is taxable. I understand from the honourable member for Flinders, who has done research into this matter, that there are about 20 different circumstances under which the family home is taxable under the capital gains tax. Later tonight the honourable member for Flinders will indicate this. If anybody who is listening to the broadcast wants to go into greater detail he does not even have to send a reply paid envelope to the honourable member for Flinders; he will receive from the honourable member the examples and will be asked to beware.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to quote from a letter I have received from Mr Bullock, the President of the Taxpayers Association of New South Wales, on the $200 impost for applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. If anybody wishes to appeal against the decision of the Taxation Commissioner he now has to pay $200 instead of $2, irrespective of the size of the claim. That is the key point I make. I am not worried about a big business or anybody with a pretty big claim having to pay $200 because that would be regarded as a respectable business expense. I am really having a go about this on behalf of the small taxpayer or the small business person, partnership or whatever. I will give some indication of why that impost is a great difficulty for such people. The Taxpayers Association of New South Wales says this:

This Association takes strong objection to the recent decision to impose a $200 fee (with or without the possibility of its refund) payable by a taxpayer to have an objection against an income tax assessment referred to the Taxation Division of an Administration Appeals Tribunal.
If this decision is allowed to stand, it will result in a sorry state for taxpayers particularly those who object against assessments and their objection has been arbitrarily disallowed.

Such a taxpayer would be faced with the dilemma-is the payment of a relatively considerable fee worthwhile because of the amount of tax involved or should he not proceed with the objection and allow Taxation Office bureaucracy to over ride justice.

The vast majority of taxpayers have had, at some time, adjustments made to their returns of income. In some cases they were probably correct and proper but, too many times, it is apparent that they have been made in an arbitrary fashion by inexperienced or zealous Taxation Officers.
I suggest that we have all had examples of these brought to our attention in our electorate offices. The letter continues:
That many are inexperienced has been freely admitted by senior officers of the Taxation Office.
Up to a few weeks ago, the referring of an objection to a Board of Review required a payment of $2. That fee was abolished and is now to be replaced by the 1imposition of $200 to a like body.

It is sad that many taxation assessors are both inexperienced and are revenue minded with little regard to fairness to a taxpayer. With the knowledge that ``it will not be worthwhile for a taxpayer to pay $200 for an objection to be proceeded with'', this type of Officer will probably take autocratic action and, in effect, be the final arbitrator of the objection.
Such a position cannot be allowed to remain. If it does it will be the death-knell, in a practical sense, of the small taxpayer's right to fairness.
Our members have repeatedly observed-
I am talking about the Taxpayers Association of New South Wales, from whose letter I am quoting-
that objections have been perfunctorily disallowed and only when application is made for reference to a Board of Review is the objection considered properly and in many cases then allowed.

Perhaps a small fee could apply only when the amount of tax in dispute is in excess of $2,000, but overall this Association feels that justice to taxpayers will arise only if the relatively high fee of $200 is not imposed. Justice, particularly to small taxpayers, must be done and be seen to be done.
That is a letter from Mr Don Bullock, the President of the Taxpayers Association of New South Wales, to the Treasurer. He was kind enough to send me a copy.

I have also had a letter from a firm of chartered accountants in Malvern which deals with returns from relatively small taxpayers. The letter states that it is a firm of chartered accountants managing the financial and taxation affairs of a large group of clients. It expresses concern about the increase in the fee to $200. The letter reads:

In cases where the amount of tax in dispute is small any further referral will now be financially important for a number of clients. This position does not foster any feelings of justice being administered.
This fee appears to be aimed at the removal of the legal rights for a large group of the community who are ``small'' taxpayers.

In the case of a dispute over the disallowance of a small expense item in a husband and wife partnership, to pursue the matter beyond the objection level will cost each partner $200, that is $400m in respect of one item in dispute.

If the honourable member for Macarthur intends to speak in relation to this matter, I would ask him to justify a partnership of husband and wife having to pay $400 to lodge an objection against a relatively small disparity. Perhaps the honourable member could explain why that is a good idea. The firm of chartered accountants goes on to say:

The Australian Taxation Office has an approach in certain cases where a dispute is likely, to issue assessments not only to the head trust, but also any subsidiary trust and subsequent beneficiaries of these trusts. That is, the same income is being assessed three times or possibly even more. Because of the contentious nature of the matters in dispute, objections are being automatically disallowed. Therefore each decision must be referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal at a cost of $200.

In one recent case in this office, where objections are being disallowed, the cost of referral of the matter will be $25,000, in respect of one item in dispute. This cost is in addition to legal costs etc. The effect may possibly be that all legal rights of the taxpayers involved to defend a bona-fide commercial transaction may be removed.

That is a matter which the Government must answer. I raised it previously in a debate in this House. I got a thoroughly unsatisfactory response from the Minister Assisting the Treasurer. I believe that the Treasurer ought to come into the House and give an explanation on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have come in to listen to you.

—I am grateful once again that the Minister Assisting the Treasurer is present. But I am becoming increasingly uncertain as to the leverage which the Minister has in regard to the Treasurer. I am beginning to worry about whether the Minister, who so often has to come into the House to represent the Treasurer, who treats the House with total contempt, is looked upon by the Treasurer with any more sense of regard than the Treasurer has for Senator Richardson. That is beginning to worry me. Nice chaps get beaten up by people like the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also a letter from a firm of chartered accountants in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), who represents an electorate in Wollongong and who is concerned about small taxpayers, partnerships and so on, would be concerned about this matter. The letter states:

It appears to me that the referral fee is particularly going to disadvantage those persons in the lower income group. By this I mean that it will not be worthwhile referring the matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if the value of the tax involved is less than $200.

A person who is in the lower income group and paying tax at the rate of 24.42 cents in the dollar will be most severely disadvantaged. The disallowance which represents an amount of $200 in tax in this particular case is $819.

So, in regard to somebody who is paying tax at the rate of 24c in the dollar, the $200 tax would relate to a claim of $819. Such a person would be prejudiced in this matter and would regard it as not worth his while to proceed. I think that is disgraceful. Anybody who represented the area which is represented by the Minister for Housing and Construction would be particularly worried about this matter. The letter continues:

On the other hand, a person paying tax at the highest rate, namely 57.08 cents in the dollar need only have a disallowance of $350 in claims to equal the $200 in tax. The idea of referring a taxation objection disallowance to the Board of Review (now the Administrative Appeals Tribunal) was to provide a cheap and inexpensive way for a taxpayer to have a person or persons outside the taxation office review their objection.

Now this is not possible without a particular financial penalty. All I can say in regard to this quite complex series of measures is that it is yet another series of Bills which add to the 1,000 or so pages of additional taxation legislation that this Government has introduced. All of these measures are there for one purpose-that is, to raise more money from the overburdened taxpayer. They are there because the Government has spent too much on things on which it should not have spent taxpayers' money. That is the bottom line: Too much spent, too much tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is usual in a debate on anything dealing with the Australian taxation system, we seem to hear the same diatribe from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) who claims, in talking about the reform of the Australian tax system, that this Government is complicating the system and introducing legislation which amounts to mountains of pages and reams of material that people have to read in order to understand it. The honourable member, during his discourse, made reference to the fact that I stood behind the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he made promises about reforming the Australian tax system-the RATS system, as he called it. I place on the record that I am proud to stand behind that particular commitment and the reform of the Australian tax system. I tell honourable members opposite that the rats in the system came from their side. I refer to the rorting of the Australian tax system, which came about when the Opposition and its cronies, when they were in government, failed to grasp the nettle and failed to introduce any fairness in the tax system. It continued along its way of protecting the rorters of the system throughout the taxation area.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic premise that we are faced with is that this Government is committed to creating a fair tax system in which everyone pays his or her fair share of tax. The range of opportunities and measures that we have introduced have contributed greatly to making the system much fairer. It must also be pointed out by way of introduction why these measures were necessary. The honourable member for Mackellar claimed that we were feeding some insatiable desire for funds so that we could continue along the road of public expenditure. That is absolute nonsense. Of course this was done so that the tax cuts, which will come into effect on 1 December and 1 July next year, will be neutralised in revenue terms. That is exactly what this Government is about. This is the way the tax changes should have been made long ago when those opposite were in power and had the opportunity to make them. Did they do it? No, they did not.

The honourable member for Mackellar went through a range of different matters in his discourse. He talked about provisional tax and I was very pleased to hear him say that he was quite happy to accept the changes that would be made by the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) in the area of provisional tax. If the legislation stopped the rorting or someone not paying his fair share of tax he was quite in favour of it. I endorse those sentiments 100 per cent. The Bill is aiming to give effect to a Budget decision that the Government had taken to amend the income tax law to overcome arrangements for the avoidance of provisional tax. What has happened in the past is that there has been an avoidance by people paying provisional tax. From year to year there has been a manipulation in the distribution of net income of closely held partnerships or trust estates between partners and beneficiaries. Through this rorting of the system people have been able to get away with not paying a fair share of taxation and, of course, the burden has always fallen on those people who are least able to pay.

This Government has taken measures which will effectively deny to a taxpayer the right to vary provisional tax on account of a reduction in income from a family partnership or family trust estate-of course that measure is defined in the Bill before us tonight-where the Commissioner considers that the reduction is the result of an arrangement that, objectively viewed, had the dominant purpose of reducing the provisional tax. So this legislation is cleaning up the tax system. Once again it is an opportunity for this Government, and rightly so, to clean up the tax system and to make it fairer all round.

The honourable member for Mackellar also raised the question of retrospectivity. From my reading of the Bill-I certainly stand corrected by those who have framed it-it would appear that it is a one-off measure that will raise revenue in 1986-87. So retrospectivity is not an issue and therefore I would assume that those opposite-where have they all gone?-would support this part of the legislation and, I would hope, the rest of it. Mention was also made about the capital gains tax. Of course the same old things are dredged up when the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax or any of the other measures we have introduced that will improve the fairness of the tax system are mentioned. Those opposite are out to protect their cronies-that is a very good word coming hot on the heels of the Queensland election-who have rorted the system and have protected the tax avoiders who have been in Australia under the stewardship of the coalition Government. We, as a Government committed to tax reform, have gone a long way down the track to affecting that matter. What is conveniently overlooked about the capital gains tax is that it is not, by western standards, a very harsh tax. It makes allowance for discounting for inflationary effects and it raises a number of other issues that indicate that the tax, as a collection of capital, is not a particularly harsh one and that is an important point to make.

Once again the honourable member for Mackellar whinged about the fact that the advisers of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not brief the Opposition. He went on to say that when the offer was made it was somehow inconvenient to those opposite. I say to that: So what and bad luck. If the offer is made for the Opposition to get a briefing on a piece of legislation and if it thinks it is important enough, it will be there no matter what happens. A measured response was also given to the question of tribunal and court fees. The honourable member for Mackellar talked at length about the appeal fee, the $200 filing fee. He quoted from a number of letters from accountants who were whingeing on behalf of their constituent groups. They said: `It is really too bad that we will have to pay all this money and something has to be done'. I am amazed that the accountancy lobby in general voter land is so concerned about its clients. One would have thought that accountants would love the opportunity to lodge appeals on behalf of their clients, to think about the little extra money that would spin their way. I am pleased to see that the accountants have a conscience streak. I have taken on board the information the honourable member for Mackellar brought to this House tonight about how concerned accountants are for their own little taxpayers.

Have I been the only one who has picked up the point that the honourable member for Mackellar seems to miss a lot of points about what the Government is doing? He seems to miss everything that we are doing. He has not had enough explanations; the Treasurer was not available to tell him something; there was no explanatory memorandum and, of course, without that he cannot understand what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you are right.

—I thought that because when tax is paid by the normal people who pay their tax, they put in their tax return. It is processed and if the taxpayer is dissatisfied with the assessment he can lodge an objection, but did the honourable member for Mackellar mention that?
—No, he did not.
—Did he mention that there is no fee for an objection?
—No.

—I am glad that the honourable member for Charlton can confirm that because I listened to everything the honourable member for Mackellar said in the half hour that he was on his feet and he did not say that once. He deliberately left out that point. He then went on to ask: What about the $200 fee? That arises if a person is still dissatisfied with the objection. If a person, having gone down one road, is not happy with the assessor and the Commissioner of Taxation's ruling, he can appeal and at that stage a $200 fee is appropriate. Why not? Time and time again we hear honourable member's opposite whinge about government expenditure and giving away things for free. Let me say this: If having gone down the objection road and if that has not satisfied some people-obviously one suspects that fairly large amounts are involved; I am not talking about the small taxpayers whom the honourable member for Mackellar would have us believe are worried about this legislation-such people would lodge $200. What the honourable member for Mackellar did not say was that if an appeal is successful the appeal fee is refunded. I cannot see anything fairer than that in the system. It comes back to the basic point we on this side raise and that is that all of these measures are designed to improve the fairness of the system, to get people to pay their fair share of taxation and not to promote the rorts and ramps that have been operative in this country for far too long.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in Question Time in a number of questions on taxation issues those opposite expressed the view that once again this Government had not done anything, that opportunities were available in the past to use obscure parts of the legislation to pick up some rorts in the system. The Treasurer clearly indicated, as did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that there are sections in the Income Tax Assessment Act, for example section 26 (e), that have always been there but were never used by those opposite. Did the great champion of fairness in taxation, the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), use it? No. Why not? It was because it was too hard, it could not be done, it was complex. Yet the honourable member for Mackellar said that the legislation this Government is introducing is too complex, that he cannot understand it. Those on this side seem to be able to comprehend it; those people in the electorate of Cunningham to whom the honourable member for Mackellar referred and those in the adjoining seat of Macarthur in Wollongong seem to understand it because there have not been too many whinges or complaints about the legislation we have introduced to make the tax system fairer. I think I can speak on behalf of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) who is at the table. I do not know of too many people from Wollongong who have whinged about the fairness we are trying to inject into the system.

I think a comment was also made by the Prime Minister which is very relevant to this whole debate and that is that this Government would be pleased to fight the next election on the tax policies of this Government. I stand right behind that statement because when will we find out what are the Opposition's policies on these issues? Will the Opposition keep them under wraps until the day after the election and say: `This is what we would have done had we had the opportunity to give it to you'. Where are the Opposition's policies on taxation? The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar, rants and raves about this stuff. He said `It is all no good' or `We support this part if it is not retrospective and maybe we will not support that because some of our colleagues who are accountants will not like it'. However, does he offer any alternatives? Has anybody in this House heard an alternative from the alternative Treasurer?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—No. Has anyone in this House heard an alternative from the alternative Prime Minister?
—No.

—No. We have been waiting for two years and not one statement has been made on taxation. We are waiting with bated breath. I am particularly waiting for the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who gave me some papers that will form the basis of his contribution to this debate. I am waiting with bated breath to hear what he will say and for him to tell me how he and his Party will stop the rorts in the system, how his cronies have benefited over the years and what he will do to make the tax system any fairer than this Government has been able to make it. These Bills will go down that road to improve the system, to make it fairer, and we are very pleased to see them in here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say right from the outset that when we return to government after the next election we will put a stop to the Labor Government's legislation to tax people's family homes. That is the first thing we will be doing. Is it not interesting that we had lots of interjections from the other side of the House when the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) made the point that there are at least 20 circumstances in which family homes are subject to tax? But did we hear any defence of those provisions from the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin)? We heard none whatsoever. The honourable member talked about the rates of tax payable on capital gains under this legislation which has been introduced as part of the tax reform package. The fact is that we have some of the highest rates of capital gains tax in the world because all capital gains are taxed at the marginal rate. When everybody else is trying to drop capital gains tax because it is seen as a disincentive to capital formation and employment we are introducing it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) introduces a number of amendments to taxation laws. As honourable members will have gathered from my remarks, I will be concentrating on those sections of the taxation laws which relate to the capital gains tax. Capital gains tax has been the subject of a lot of debate in Australian politics in the last few years. Conventional wisdom is that Malcolm Fraser ensured a coalition victory in 1980 when he ran some advertisements which suggested that Labor would tax people's homes. In 1983 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told us that there would be no capital gains tax. In 1984 the then Leader of the Opposition predicted that as sure as night follows day, Labor would introduce a capital gains tax. Well, Malcolm Fraser was right when he said that under Labor one's money would be safer under the bed. He was also right when he said in the Liberal Party advertisements in the 1980 campaign:

Labor is committed to a new tax which would hit middle income earners just as violently as the wealthy. This so-called wealth tax would steal the savings of people who through superannuation, insurance policies and small investments have attempted to provide for their old age or their children. It would attack hundreds of thousands of Australian families who own modest homes which have risen in value.
That is absolutely right. He also said-and I quote selectively:
If you sell your house to buy another then you would pay a capital gains tax on that.
As I will show tonight, that is also true. He also said:
Don't be taken in by the way Labor glosses over its commitments to new taxes.
He asked:
After all, where else would they get the money for all their schemes.

Malcolm Fraser was dead right-Labor is taxing people's family homes. When people wake up to what is going on there will be a revolt in this country which will make the uprising on the fringe benefits tax look like a Sunday school picnic. The question in that advertisement headed `Where else would they get the money?' was particularly accurate. The Government said in September 1985 when legislation as brought down and on other occasions: `Look, do not worry about this capital gains tax. It is going to bring in only $25m. It is absolutely harmless'. In fact, the Government could not even predict in the Budget Papers what the figure would be.

Let me contrast that with what was said in a letter that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) sent to his colleagues for their consideration at the Australian Labor Party's National Conference in Hobart this year. What was his prediction about how much the capital gains tax would bring in? He predicted that it would bring in $300m. So publicly he says $25m and privately he says $300m. I ask the people of Australia to make up their own minds which of those two figures they would be more likely to believe.

This Bill was introduced in a great hurry. Nobody had a chance to read the fine print. As with all of Labor's tax legislation, it is incredibly complex, which might explain the honourable member for Macarthur's lack of understanding of it. Within weeks it became apparent that the Government had made a monumental blunder and that the tax was going to catch a whole lot of situations that the Government claimed were never intended. This Bill attempts to rectify the situation of just one of those circumstances-that related to options. Contrary to the statement that the tax would bring in only $25m, we found out a few weeks after the introduction of the Bill that in fact it would bring in something like $100m just for that one item of options alone. How the Minister in his second reading speech on these amendments could say that the amendments are not expected to have any significant effect on revenue is absolutely news to me. They are going to have a very significant impact on revenue and potential revenue. Of course, that will put an end to a windfall gain of $100m that the Government was going to receive.

There is no doubt that the capital gains tax legislation before us tonight represents capital gains tax mark 2. There is also no doubt in my mind that this will be the first of very many more amendments to Labor's capital gains tax. It is so complicated that very few people really understand it. I have received a copy of a paper that Professor Parsons of the law faculty of Sydney University gave to a recent conference in Victoria. I am told that Professor Parsons is an acknowledged authority on taxation matters. That paper did not receive much publicity because not even the Press can understand the complexities of Labor's capital gains tax legislation. But some of the professor's comments give an indication of the problem which is still to be addressed. I have plucked out some parts of what he said in that paper, and I will quote them selectively. He said, amongst other things:

The operation of the tax is haphazard . . . Grand ironies in the tax reform legislation of recent months will be found in the capital gains tax provisions . . . In these and other of its provisions the capital gains tax legislation enters on a rogue operation . . . The prospect is thus opened of the allowance of an expense in determining a net capital gain or loss and the allowance of the same expense as a deduction against assessable income.
He also said:
Problems in the application of the definition of costbase must arise.
Lastly he said:
Some attempts are made in the specific provisions of Part 111 (a) relating to trusts but they are sadly inadequate.

This is a damning indictment of the drafting of Labor's capital gains tax legislation. Just a couple of months after bringing in its legislation the Government is very much on the back foot in introducing these amendments. The amendments do not go nearly far enough and the Government should pinch another one of the Opposition's policies and proceed to abolish this tax lock stock and barrel.

I turn now to the specific provisions of the legislation. The effect of clause 31 is to define the basis upon which a capital gain is to be calculated. Let us take a simple example-the case of Mr and Mrs Smith who have been using part of their family home as a study or an office. They acquired the property after September 1985 and they have been claiming part of their electricity bill off their business-a fairly standard sort of situation likely to affect tens of thousands of Australians. Under those circumstances, Mr and Mrs Smith's home is subject to Labor's capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that is intended or unintended?

—There is no doubt that it is intended because I have received a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation today which confirms that it is in fact an intended consequence of Labor's capital gains tax. Let us return to the example of Mr and Mrs Smith and assume that Mr Smith unfortunately dies. Mrs Smith would automatically become the owner of Mr Smith's half share. This is a very standard transaction. Mrs Smith decides to sell the home because it has unhappy memories for her, and most of the children have left home. When it comes to calculating the capital gains tax on the share that she has inherited the tax then will be calculated on the basis of the value of the house when it was purchased by them as a couple. In other words, the cost basis will include his half share of the date of the purchase. Under the legislation as it is prior to amendment, the date of acquisition-on my reading of the Bill-of that half share would be the date of death. The amendment, therefore, extends the operation of the capital gains tax. If that all sounds complicated, let me put it in simpler terms. This increases the tax liability on jointly held assets by widows and widowers. The Opposition is opposed to taxing family homes.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 36 relates to situations where, for reasons outside a person's control, he or she has to sell a property. Under the capital gains tax legislation all properties owned prior to 19 September 1985 are tax exempt. Basically the law says that if someone is forced to sell a property and buy another one, that person will continue to get the exemption on the new asset. I think that is only fair and it is in fact recognised in the legislation. The trouble is that the terms of section 160zzk are very narrow. The amendment in clause 36 gives a person more time to meet the narrow criteria which must be met to obtain that roll over exemption. It is fair enough that if a property is compulsorily acquired-if the property was owned before September 1985-because of circumstances beyond a person's control and he moves into a new place, that new place will also be exempt.

The provision that the acquisition be by compulsion is a very narrow limitation on that roll over clause. Take the case of the Commonwealth, which has a policy of acquiring properties under what it calls acquisition by agreement. The Commonwealth is, for example, following that policy with the acquisition of properties for the extension of Sydney Airport, and there are about 250 properties in that one case. In those situations the acquisition is not compulsory and therefore those people will all lose the benefit of the roll over provision in the capital gains tax legislation. It is ironic, is it not, that the Government claims to make fair provision for people whose property is being compulsorily acquired and yet another government department, by its policies and by its actions, in fact negates the roll over provision in the capital gains tax legislation?

In the last 10 sitting days we saw the Treasurer dodging and weaving on questions of the capital gains tax. But it has not only been in the last couple of weeks that he has done that because on 17 July I wrote to him on behalf of some constituents of mine who had a gun at their heads and who were forced to sell properties. I pointed out to him the narrowness of the criteria as they related to them. I still have had no response. If the Treasurer is taking some notice of the contributions made in this debate I hope that a response in relation to those people whom I represent will be forthcoming much sooner than it might otherwise have been.

Since the enactment of the capital gains tax legislation I have prepared a list of 20 circumstances in which the family home is subject to a capital gains tax. A moment ago I mentioned one of them. Clause 37 of this amending Bill, which we are debating today, removes one situation which I have to confess I had not foreseen. In fact although there were 21 the Government will remove one; so we now have 20. When the legislation was rushed through the Parliament the Government made a mistake.

Again take the situation of Mr and Mrs Smith owning the family home. Assume that Mr Smith dies and leaves the property to his only child and the property from the date of death becomes subject to the capital gains tax even if the only child is the sole beneficiary and has lived in the house as his permanent home. The problem is that the exemption requires Mrs Smith to continue living in the house until the point in time at which the child becomes the legal owner of the house. That is as I understand it. I attempted to clarify it but there was no opportunity for me to do so. But I would still like clarification on that because it is very relevant to the interpretation of that clause. The document refers to this as a technical deficiency. On my reading of it that is a very generous definition of the term and of the use of the English language.

There are many other technical deficiencies in this legislation which have not yet been addressed and in the few minutes available to me I want to give some examples. Take the very common situation where somebody sees a house which he likes and decides to purchase it and in fact does purchase it. That person then signs a contract but takes longer than three months to sell his old place. For every day that it takes him longer than the three months to sell the old place, he will pay a capital gains tax. I ask honourable members on the other side, when they contribute to this debate, to give us some justification for taxing people's family homes in that instance. The Australian Labor Party has a deliberate policy of high interest rates. If someone buys a new home and if it takes him longer to sell his old home he could be paying pretty high bridging finance. Most people in that situation would, if they had the opportunity, rent out the old place until it was sold. But as soon as they do that, for the whole time that the property is rented, that house, that family home, is subject to Labor's capital gains tax.

Take another situation: Say the local road construction authority in metropolitan Melbourne or Sydney decides to widen the street and take four or five feet off the frontage of a person's property. When it takes that property by compulsory acquisition the compensation received will be subject to Labor's capital gains tax. It gives with one hand and takes with another.

In my electorate many people like to buy residential allotments in rural areas. Ten-acre blocks are very popular and are often zoned rural-residential and can be used only for residential purposes. If someone buys a block which is in excess of 2 hectares, which is about five acres, the land in excess of that five acres will be subject to Labor's capital gains tax, even though it may be used for purely private purposes, such as grazing the kids' ponies. Is that fair? Is that an encouragement to people to live in the country and enjoy a country life? No, it is not; it is another example of Labor taxing people's family homes.

Under Labor's capital gains tax the Government will let someone claim an exemption for his principal home even though that person is temporarily absent from the home. That sounds fine, but the exemption is available only if that person, when he returns home, writes to the Commissioner of Taxation. A person must write to the Commissioner as a precondition for his not taxing the family home. The Treasurer has shown clearly in the Parliament in the last few weeks that he is not too well versed in the operation of the capital gains tax or the fringe benefits tax for that matter. If he does not know the law, how on earth can he expect ordinary Australians to understand the complexity of Labor's tax laws so that they can avoid paying a capital gains tax on their family homes?

I turn to clause 37 of the Bill under discussion. If the beneficiary of an estate inherits a dwelling that is the principal residence of the deceased, no capital gains tax will be payable if the property is disposed of within 12 months. If, as the beneficiary, that person does not use the home as the principal place of residence and if the sale of the property is delayed beyond this time limit of 12 months, the tax will be payable. Anybody who knows anything about legal affairs knows that to finalise an estate often takes longer than 12 months. Why, in those circumstances, should people be subject to Labor's capital gains tax on their family homes?

Let me give honourable members this one last example, which has been confirmed to me today in writing by the Commissioner of Taxation. This is again a very common situation of a person who buys a home and before he moves into that home he decides to renovate it, but it takes some time because builders and plumbers can be a bit slow when someone is in a hurry to move in. For the whole of the time that it takes that person to have the property renovated, and before he moves into it, his home will be subject to Labor's capital gains tax.

This Government says it brought this tax in to get stuck into the tax cheats and the people who avoid tax. But are ordinary Australians, who fail to notify the Tax Commissioner that they have returned home, tax cheats? Are young couples, who buy a block of land and who are forced to move home within 12 months after erecting a house on their block and who then have to pay a capital gains tax, tax cheats and tax avoiders? Are the people in my electorate who want to live on a 10-acre block tax cheats because they simply chose to live in a semi-rural environment to bring up their children?

This Government claims to support home ownership in this country, but the fact is that wherever we turn, Labor will be there with its hands in our pockets, subjecting our family homes to its capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—The Minister says that it is nonsense. The reality is that the Minister for Housing and Construction has not got a clue. The thousands of people who receive the $4,000 or $5,000 home loan assistance grant from his Government will also find his Government taxing their family homes.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill, the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Transfers of Marketable Securities) Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2). We have just heard from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) about his favourite topic which appears to be the defence of those people who sought to make profits or capital gains outside the system where they were not required to pay any tax. It appears to me that the honourable member for Flinders has a real fetish for defending those in the community who do not wish to pay their share of tax as the majority of the community do. He has raised some very spurious claims tonight in this debate.
—I will give you the letters from the Tax Commissioner.

—I also have the letter from the Commissioner of Taxation addressed to Mr P. K. Reith, MP, Parliament House, Canberra. I noticed that the honourable member did not use one quote in his speech from the answers given to him by the second Commissioner. He selectively chose words and placed them in a context in order to create the impression that the family home would be taxed. I will deal with that in a moment. There is every reason why we had to have a taxation reform package introduced in this Parliament. There is every reason why on 1 December this year and 1 July next year we will see cuts in income tax rates of 60c in the dollar down to 49c and from 46c down to 40c. It is a legacy of seven years of conservative rule whereby, in that time, every possible method was adopted to avoid paying those rates of 46c and 60c in the dollar. In fact, many of the tax reform measures have been necessarily put into place to combat some very shifty footwork by some of our very zealous accountants working on behalf of those in the community who did not feel that they should be paying 46c or 60c in the dollar if they could possibly avoid it. We cannot blame people for finding the legal means of paying the minimum amount of tax. It is an accepted past time in Australia for most Australians to be able to say honestly and clearly that if they can find a legal means of avoiding tax why not do so.

SPEECH.PARA: At times it could be morally said that perhaps some of the methods that have been developed within the laws of the country were not necessarily the intention of the law, but certainly they were not outside the law so I do not condemn those people who have used those methods. But I do condemn those who for that seven year period controlled the Treasury benches and who never at any stage took on the issue of tax reform. They knew that the 46c and the 60c in the dollar issue was impacting on more and more people in the community as inflation was pushing the wage levels up and as money values were deteriorating. Very quickly we found that many people in Australia on ordinary wages were moving into the 46c and 60c area. But nothing was done to overcome that problem. We saw the greatest growth industry in Australia, the tax evasion and avoidance industry which has flourished for many years. It has taken the Hawke Government with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to have the courage to have a go at this issue and to put back into the taxation system fairness and equity. These Bills before the House certainly are designed to do just that.

The honourable member for Flinders certainly was drawing a long bow at times in trying to justify his support for abolishing the capital gains tax. Whilst the Opposition may say that the taxation levels are too high and that they should be reduced we know that it did nothing about it-it certainly has no policy which designates, even now, what it would do in the 60c or 46c area. It is now law in this country, passed by this Parliament, that those tax rates will be coming down, yet we still do not hear from the Opposition any method which it claims will make the tax system much fairer and more equitable. We have in the debate in Australia a process of attacking packages in the taxation reform. Packages such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax are major issues when they are only part of a reform package. I am positive from my experience of moving around Australia with the task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the message getting through loud and clear is that the hollowness of the campaign against those tax measures is being overcome by the knowledge of many in the community that their tax cuts on 1 December will come through, that further tax cuts on 1 July will come through, and that many of the people who will be paying the extra tax under the FBT and, if necessary, under the capital gains tax, will have that tax adjusted in their taxation liability, except in those areas in the capital gains tax where people have to pay a share that they did not have to pay before. We are seeing a massive turnover in shares on the Australian share market. Today the buying and selling of shares on the Australian market over time will be taxed. Those people who are making profits will have to pay their fair share of tax.

What the honourable member for Flinders did not mention in the debate when he tried to make out that the private home would be taxed-I challenge him on nearly every point he made in relation to the private home-was that the private home would no longer be a private home. He gave a reason why it would no longer be a private home; because somebody would be running a business from that private home, a business such as a doctors surgery from some part of the residence, and seeks, as a business, to make a taxation claim for the electricity charges, the renovations, and the repairs. Once that portion of the residence is designated as a business, and since the date of the announcement of the capital gains tax, why should any person running a business be entitled to make taxation claims on the one hand and expect not to be taxed under the capital gains tax or the fringe benefits tax on that very same principle? It is a principle we do not hear in this debate at present around Australia. We hear much from small business so-called leaders and representatives. We hear much from the honourable member for Flinders and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) who defend those in the community who want to have a taxation claim against the Tax Commissioner. They want it all back on the one hand but they do not want to declare any income from the business on the other which should show up on the credit record and be taxed. The tax reform package that this Government is bringing in will show through in the long run when people realise that the tax reform is a real reform.

I will give the House a couple of examples of some of those things that have been put forward. For instance, if Mr and Mrs Smith-as has been quoted by the honourable member for Flinders-rent a home or a private dwelling to another person, for example an only child, and that only child also has a private residence of his own, and the second residence is rented for a business purpose, the minute it is rented one can bet that the accountant will be making claims at the end of the year for any expenses because they are running it as a business. Yet the honourable member for Flinders seems to believe that because it was a family home, but no longer is such because of the circumstances, somehow we are taxing a private home. It was a private home, but the day that it changed its use and became a residence for business use it was no longer a private home. The day that the Taxation Commissioner has claims against him for repairs, expenses and the running of that home as a business, the circumstances have automatically changed.

The other measure the honourable member did not talk about was that it has to be on the real profit. The fact that someone sells a property at an inflated gain in money terms does not necessarily mean that that amount of money will be subject to tax. It is a fair and equitable tax system based on a person making a business decision to make a profit, and any profit in this country should be taxed just as those in the community pay their taxes where their profits are clear and in the open. A capital gain in those areas certainly should be taxed. I fully support that measure in the Bill. What I despise at the moment is the campaign being waged by the Opposition, an Opposition which has no taxation policies--

TALK.START.PARA: —None at all.
—It has none at all. It has a list of promises-so long that one cannot put them on one page-of what it claims it will do if it is given the opportunity.
—They are gunnas.
—Opposition members are gunnas. They are gunna do this and gunna do that. They talk of millions here and millions there but they do not say anything about where they would collect any of these funds.
—Where is the money coming from?

—Where will the money come from? The Opposition is claiming that it will put back billions of dollars into the coffers and that there will be no capital gains tax, which will go lock, stock and barrel, and no fringe benefits tax, which will also go lock, stock and barrel. The barrel is going to be very empty if the Opposition ever gets the opportunity to put a policy into practice.

SPEECH.PARA: For the first time in many years those in the community whom the Opposition supports will have to carry their weight and pay their way as other taxpayers have done. In this Budget, $22,700m will be collected from pay as you earn taxpayers to be used for our hospitals, roads and schools and the welfare and health of the nation. Under the tax reform package we will collect between $500m and $700m just in fringe benefits tax. The sum of $4,500m will go back, as tax cuts, to the pay as you earn taxpayers who have paid the $22,700m. It will be the first time in many years that many people will pay their fair share of tax on the capital gains-the real profit-they have been making and on the fringe benefits they have been getting.

I fully support the legislation and the reforms this Government has brought before the Parliament. I challenge Opposition members who keep saying that, lock, stock and barrel, they will throw out this measure and that measure but that they will give concessions here and concessions there. Never before have I heard so many words spoken or seen so much effort put in to support so few people who seem to believe that they have a divine right to the benefits of this country but also a divine right not to pay their fair share for the roads, hospitals and other amenities which other Australians, the PAYE taxpayers, are forking out for, to the tune of $22,500m.

It is time the Opposition came clean on the issue of tax reform. It is time its members stopped bleating around the country and getting behind people who have decided that they will find ways and means of not paying their 46c or 60c in the dollar. It is not the lower income people we are talking about. It is those in the 46c to 60c tax bracket who have decided that they do not want to pay. I do not deny that those tax rates are too high. They should have been fixed 10 years ago. The Opposition had its opportunity in its seven years of government to introduce some tax reform and it did nothing. We have here a tax reform package which will reduce the 46c and 60c tax rates, which are a legacy of the conservative Government. The law has passed.

The bank managers who are worried at the moment that they will have to pay something like $20 or $30 rent for the houses they have had free for years will be getting a tax cut on 1 December and a follow-up tax cut on 1 July next year. They will come out exactly where they started. For the $20 in rent they will have to pay they will probably get about $20 back in tax cuts. Then there will be nothing for the Opposition to go to the people with. It is time the Opposition knuckled down and came up with some real policies. I give the Opposition one warning. It will have nothing to fly with come six months time, because the people it is now depending on to support it will see through it as the people whom I have been meeting in the last two or three months out in the country have seen through it. I fully support the tax reform measures before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately four taxation measures: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1986, the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill 1986, the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Transfers of Marketable Securities) Bill 1986 and the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986. In the time I have I will concentrate on the first of those Bills. In addressing my remarks to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1986 I refer firstly to the provision of a $200 filing fee for applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review certain decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation. I take the strongest exception to a number of aspects of this legislation. Let me remind the House that I sought to have recorded my opposition to the termination of the operation of the taxation boards of review and the direction of those appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As I recall it, the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) also sought to have his opposition specifically recorded. I am sorry that the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), is not in the House tonight, because he contested much of what I then said and I have been proved correct.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has now confirmed the validity of the criticism and concern which I then expressed and calls into question whether the rights and opportunities of a taxpayer in dispute with the Commissioner to appeal and contest decisions he deems unfair are of any value at all. Let me illustrate how this Bill, with its filing fee, is another curtailment of those rights. In reference to a taxpayer's right of appeal let me say-and I say it in great sorrow-that I have never before, in a very long professional association with the Australian Taxation Office, found the Office to be as arrogant, unhelpful and unresponsive as it is now. It simply does not answer inquiries from taxpayers and tax agents. To get a reply in a reasonable time is impossible. Yet it issues its own demands and ruthlessly demands immediate response and compliance under threat of legal action.

As a Federal member, when I raise an issue I get-most, but not all, of the time-prompt answers and responses. But a simple request put forward recently took 10 months to elicit an answer. More often than not my involvement is sought by constituents because of their frustration and unsympathetic treatment. I know that the Office can never expect to be the most popular arm of government, but it is a matter of real concern that almost universally among taxpayers and practitioners the Taxation Office is regarded as more and more arrogant and dictatorial. More and more it ignores urgent requests for advice and guidance and more and more it is unwilling to have any regard at all for the rights of taxpayers.

Whilst I appreciate the access I have as a member of parliament, the tragedy is that practitioners and taxpayers become so frustrated that the only way they can get any consideration and response is to involve their Federal member. More and more of the constituents I see and more and more of the representations I am called upon to make involve such disputes and problems with the Taxation Office. I hope that what I say will be taken seriously and that this complete breakdown in good will and public relations which is attributable to the attitudes of the Tax Office will be seriously addressed and urgently remedied.

The filing fee is another impediment being placed in the way of taxpayers who seek to contest a decision of the Commissioner. Taxpayers who have asked the Commissioner for reconsideration and who have sought reference to a board of review are today receiving amended assessments relating to returns as far back as 1979 and 1980. The amendments include all sorts of additional interest and penalties; yet the Tax Office, which can string out decisions over such an inordinate length of time, will not extend by a single day the short period prescribed under the Income Tax Assessment Act for a taxpayer to lodge an appeal. I have found evidence of that. I have seen that peremptory action time and time again. I ask whether under any objective judgment in a democratic nation this has any similitude to justice or fair play.

What is the response of the Taxation Office and the Government to the complaints? Firstly, the Office delayed referring appeals to the boards of reviews. The delays in having appeals heard were due not only to the number of appeals but equally to the unwillingness of the Office even to refer them to the boards of review. I have said before and I say again that the removal of the boards of review was justified on grounds which do not stand scrutiny. It was a decision which most seriously reduced the rights and opportunities of a taxpayer to appeal. Further, I have said before and I say again that the expertise and experience of the boards of review and their proven record should not have been jettisoned. In my view it was a further aggregation of power to the Australian Taxation Office and a serious further impediment to a taxpayer who is aggrieved. The process of appeal was complicated and made less understandable and also less accessible. Having removed the boards of review which for a $2 deposit would consider an appeal, this Bill provides for a filing fee of $200 for applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The huge delays, the demands, the writs and the attitudes of the Australian Taxation Office have placed taxpayers in an untenable position.

Unresolved disputes over returns six or seven years old have meant that a taxpayer does not know the status of subsequent returns. He does not know whether he has to restructure his whole affairs. He does not know where he stands. Is this an unfair and insidious process of attrition? Is it a way of enforcing a decision without even the possibility of independent adjudication? Can a taxpayer insist on his rights when he contemplates the delay and the procedures confronting him and when he considers that if he insists on his legal rights he can face bankruptcy and ruin? If it is the fault of the Government denying the department personnel and facilities to remedy this situation I call on the Government to remedy without delay these deficiencies. How on earth in the light of this very real and accurate scenario which I have outlined can the Government justify now this huge increase in filing fee from $2 to $200.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can't.

—It cannot. How can any ordinary taxpayer who has been assured that he has rights and opportunities to appeal against what he perceives to be an unfair decision possibly have any confidence in those assurances? Quite the reverse applies. He has found it almost impossible to have appeals heard. In addition to all the threats, demands, writs and penalties he has to find the substantial sum of $200 to even commence the process. There is absolutely no way in the world that the Government can possibly claim that it is facilitating the taxpayers' opportunity and rights of appeal. This increase most certainly is not only a disincentive but can be an absolute bar to the opportunity to appeal.

SPEECH.PARA: This simply means that taxpayers and practitioners who have already been dismayed and frustrated in effect are being ignored. They are being told that it is indecent and unpatriotic to have the temerity to call into question any decision of the Commissioner of Taxation. They are being told that if they have the audacity to believe that they have been unjustly or unfairly dealt with and want to query that treatment they will be slugged a large sum of money if they want to pursue their democratic rights. The arrogance and delays of which I spoke are being rewarded and the aggrieved are being penalised. The whole matter of taxation justice and the whole credibility of the so-called rights of appeal certainly warrant very serious consideration. The appeal process which in so many ways has already become unwieldy, inaccessible and even farcical is now being further eroded and discouraged.

If the $200 filing fee were a step which would unravel this unholy mess I could give it some support, but it is not. It will simply reinforce the dictatorial attitudes and unsympathetic treatment which the taxpayer has to endure. It will make his despair at ever getting some assistance and redress even deeper. For that reason I condemn and completely oppose this increase as vehemently and justifiably as I opposed the dismantling of the taxation boards of review. The injustice of imposing this filing fee is not redressed by the provision that the fee will be refunded if the appeal is successful. The up-front demand for the $200, the delays and inconvenience while waiting for the appeal to be heard, the fear of penalties which may be incurred if the appeal is unsuccessful and the taxpayer cannot afford to proceed to the courts, simply mean that the ordinary aggrieved taxpayer will be deterred from appealing. Only the affluent will use this procedure. The ordinary little Australian whom this Government professes to consider is just ignored and wiped off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, 11 November, is a very significant day for a number of reasons. Traditionally, it is Remembrance Day-a day on which people in many parts of the world pause and reflect on the supreme sacrifice made by thousands upon thousands of men and women who have given their lives in pursuit of an ideal. On this day also people throughout the world, more than ever they have in the past, reflect too on the folly of war, and on the breakdowns in relationships between peoples and nations that lead to the ultimate of all struggles-bloody warfare.

SPEECH.PARA: Remembrance Day is celebrated on 11 November because on this day in 1918 the hostilities of World War I came to an end. In its day, that war was described as the Great War-as the war to end all wars. As with other wars, the vast majority of its combatants went to war in the hope that their fellow countrymen and women might never again need to go to war. Many of them died in the expectation that their friends, families and children might never know what it is to be the victims of strife and warfare.

In this year especially-the International Year of Peace-there is all the more incentive to reflect on these matters. Earlier tonight, a group of wonderful students from Kiama High School in my electorate of Throsby presented here in Parliament House a dramatic performance which explored these themes. Their presentation was viewed by some 40 members, senators and staff who received it most enthusiastically. What the students presented grew out of their research into the lives of two Australian soldiers killed in action in France during World War I. Their research began with two names on war memorials-the name Walter Farquharson found on the Kiama war memorial and the name Eric Tate inscribed on the war memorial in Kangaroo Valley.

Walter Farquharson and Eric Tate are but two of the 56,000 Australian servicemen and women killed in action in World War I, and they are but two of the 29,000 Australians killed in that war's dreadful trench warfare in France and Belgium. The students of Kiama High School, through their research, and now through their dramatic presentation of that research, have made the names Walter Farquharson and Eric Tate live again. They have rescued them from relative obscurity. They are no longer simply names engraved on stone; they are flesh and blood people who left the warm circle of families and friends, never to return. The students of Kiama High have looked at the lives of these two brave soldiers. They have looked too at their families, friends and workmates; and they have looked at the Australian society in which they grew up, and which gave purpose and meaning to their lives. The students have now presented on many occasions the fruit of their research. Using photographic slides, music and narrative, they are able to present a wonderful and very moving account of these men and of the events that led to their deaths in the mud of France and Belgium.

Walter Farquharson worked as a mailman at Kiama Post Office. He was well known and very popular. Among other activities, he was for a time the beach inspector at Kiama. In 1915, at the age of 24, he enlisted and left home. He fought at Gallipoli before being transferred to France, when he was killed at the age of 26 by an exploding shell. Eric Tate was a popular member of a Kangaroo Valley family renowned for its breeding of dairy cattle, an activity in which the young man took a keen interest. He too enlisted in 1915, and he too was killed at the age of 26 by an exploding shell.

On this day, Remembrance Day, the words on our lips are `lest we forget'. Those of us who had the privilege to witness the dramatic presentation of the Kiama High students were, I know, deeply moved by the experience. Thanks to them, we are less likely to forget. Thanks to them, the words `lest we forget' take on fresh meaning. As the students reminded us, perhaps next time we pass a war memorial, that monument and what it signifies will take on a deeper meaning. I take this opportunity of publicly and sincerely thanking the students and teachers of Kiama High School for their wonderful, thought-provoking and moving presentation. I also take this opportunity to thank the members of this chamber who saw that presentation this evening.

A small cadre of dishonest academics, employed by the War Memorial and entrusted with the history of Australians who paid the ultimate sacrifice, have betrayed that trust.
