SPEECH.PARA: Over the past three years or so, and under Dr McKernan's guiding hand, this troika conspired to turn the War Memorial bookshop into a centre for private profit. Dr McKernan redirected memorial staff into private research projects and waived or discounted research and reproduction fees on library photographic material, when he, his friends and business associates were involved in publishing ventures. Dr McKernan further used his high position to mislead, or totally ignore, the duly appointed War Memorial Council while salaried officers commissioned, wrote and profited from books ordered in large numbers by the War Memorial bookshop. Dr McKernan was responsible for the bookshop. He used the Memorial's research and publications committee to rubber stamp commercial decisions which would not have stood up in front of the War Memorial Council, had it known about them in full.

Shortly after the present War Memorial Director, Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, took over in 1983 he officially queried Dr McKernan's activities. The good doctor assured the new Director that all was above board. Earlier this year the Director again had a look at Dr McKernan and some of his mates at the Memorial and found what looked to him like graft and corruption on a grand scale. He decided to investigate further. But McKernan and company have friends in high places. One is Mr Peter Hansen, the Senior Private Secretary to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), who is responsible for the War Memorial. Mr Hansen had already ingratiated himself sufficiently to Dr McKernan and Peter Stanley to earn an acknowledgment in a book the Memorial staffers co-authored-Anzac Day-70 Years On.

Delegations went back and forward between the War Memorial and the Minister's office. The Minister, Senator Arthur Gietzelt, whose staff, incidentally, draw the highest level of travel allowance outside the office of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, already incensed over the exposure of his own misuse of the War Memorial facilities for political purposes, became involved. Instead of investigating McKernan and company, the Minister mounted a highly public investigation into Air Vice-Marshal Flemming's administration. Of the 30 or so anomalies discovered by an inquiry by chartered accountants, Arthur Young and Co., I will cite two. Firstly, in February 1983, Sydney publisher and War Memorial publications adviser, Mr John Ferguson, wrote to Dr McKernan suggesting that the War Memorial co-operate in a series of books for children titled Australians at War.

Dr McKernan did more than co-operate. He led the Memorial's research and publications committee to believe that the series would be written-and I quote-by `well known children's writers'. He then hired himself, disengaged himself after a query from the Director, and put in his wife and his deputy, Dr Margaret Browne, to write the series. He then authorised an extravagant print run through the War Memorial bookshop. Neither of these people are children's writers, let alone well-known ones. The Memorial's committee and governing council were never informed as to the identity of the authors. A total of 26,000 books of the series were stocked from May 1984 to February this year at a cost to the Memorial of $35,000. By the end of June a paltry 2,587 had been sold, leaving the Memorial considerably out of pocket, but leaving the McKernan and Browne households with handy amounts through author's fees and royalty payments.

Secondly, we move to some private enterprise on the part of Dr McKernan's researcher, Peter Stanley. In February 1985 the research and publications committee approved expenditure of $63,000 for a Memorial guidebook. But neither it, nor the Council, realised it was endorsing a venture authored by Mr Stanley, in conjunction with the Sydney publisher, Mr John Ferguson, whom I mentioned earlier. Mr Stanley wrote the book A guide to the Australian War Memorial, and John Ferguson published it. Through Mr Stanley's boss, Dr McKernan, highest priority was given to requests for material from the photographic library, disrupting normal work. Even without the illegal use of the Memorial's facilities, that cost ran $6,200 over budget. The salaried staffer, Stanley, and the publications adviser, Ferguson, now have a total bill in to the War Memorial for $69,200.

It gets worse. The 160-page glossy guidebook, authorised by Dr McKernan's protege, has never gone on public sale as 35 major mistakes have been discovered in the text. For example, on page 70 Mr Stanley had the wrong Australian battalion ambushed at Long Tan, the most celebrated and costly action by Australian troops in Vietnam.

He described ACFR as being concerned with democracy, the promotion of freedom and free enterprise, ever increasing taxes and other government charges and authoritarian trendyism and coercive utopianism.

In other words, ACFR is concerned to attack all the means by which there can be any hope of redistributing wealth and power in our community to those most in need. To get back to the Bulletin, the article by Peter Kelly pointed out that it was the Moonies who were actually sponsoring the third annual conference on interdisciplinary approaches to peace through the Professors World Peace Academy and thus the ACFR was aiding and abetting the infamous Sun Mejung Moon Unification Church. Suffice to say that some of the right wing speakers, who had initially been attracted to the conference, drew a line at participating in a joint venture with the Moonies and declined to attend.

One of the best critiques of the New Right was contained in a speech by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) given on Australia Day entitled: `The False Patriots of the New Right'. I commend the speech to all those people who are interested in unmasking the true aims of these people whose sole motive is narrow self-interest. Let me conclude by quoting from that speech:

The contrast between ourselves and the New Right lies in the true meaning of consensus politics. The approach that encourages us to discuss our problems, to consider where we are as a country and where we want to go. The approach that is not content to apportion blame and identify scapegoats. The approach that searches for solutions, fosters agreement and encourages people to work together for their mutual well-being.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am often intrigued in this chamber to hear one or two members of the Government object to being called `socialists', such as in the context of the expression `the Hawke Socialist Government'. Members of the Labor Party, after all, sign a pledge supporting socialism in the Party platform when they win pre-selection to stand as candidates for the Party. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself is even on record as having said in the 1970s:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that ultimately the welfare of the people of Australia will be best served when the means of production, distribution and exchange are removed from private ownership and are owned by the people.

Karl Marx could not have put it better himself. Some Government members are prepared to admit that they are socialists, but only in the watered-down version of being `democratic socialists'. To me that is a contradictory term, like `hot ice' or `pregnant virginity'. But what also intrigues me is Government members' use such as we heard from the previous speaker-of words such as `fascist' or `nazi', which they sometimes use to label members of the Opposition who advocate philosophies or policies different from their own.

I wonder whether Government members realise what `socialism' and `fascism' mean and that in many ways these two `isms' have very similar meanings. We all understand what communism is: It is where the state owns and controls everything, and everyone is supposed to receive the same wage. Communism, of course, is a particular variant of socialism. This is acknowledged in the fact that the world's main communist country, Russia, calls itself the Union of Soviet Socialist-I emphasise the word `Socialist'-Republics, the USSR. To Marx and Engels the words `communism' and `socialism' were synonymous; there was no distinction between them. In fact, all countries ruled at present by communist regimes describe themselves officially as socialist countries, not as communist countries. Communism and socialism are opposed to the freedom of the individual and so are classified as totalitarian.

I mention these things because another `ism' that is also totalitarian in nature, and that is also a particular variant of socialism, is fascism. Fascism first appeared in Italy in 1922 under Mussolini, who incidentally was an ex-social democrat. Italian fascism actually began with a split in the ranks of Marxian socialism. In England, fascism emerged with an ex-Labour Party Minister, Oswald Mosley, a socialist, who created the British Union of Fascists. A special type of fascism also spread to Germany and was adopted by Adolf Hitler. Like the Italian brand, this type of fascism had a strong element of militarism in it and was called nazism. But make no mistake: German fascism was both totalitarian and socialist in nature. Adolf Hitler's Party was even called the German Socialist Labour Party and was regarded not only as anti-capitalist but also strongly socialist. In fact, its slogan encompassed its philosophy-namely, `the Commonwealth or State ranks above private profits'. This slogan implies that profit-making business harms the vital interests of the majority and that there should be public control over production and distribution. This, of course, is classic socialism and is the antithesis of what we in the coalition stand for.

We strongly believe that an indispensable prerequisite of democracy and of the rights of individuals lies in economic freedom. If this is stripped away by the elements of compulsion contained in socialism, communism or fascism, we move towards a totalitarian state. So when the coalition advocates such policies as, say, voluntary unionism, because we believe in the rights of the individual rather than the individual having to be made subservient to the mob, and Labor members opposite call us fascists, they know not of what they are accusing us. Fascism is a totalitarian doctrine, just like socialism or communism. It is anti the individual and pro some type of dictatorship being in control. It is against everything we stand for but very similar to what the Labor Party stands for. So if Government members want to call us names, let them call us libertarians or free enterprisers. At least then they will be correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to enter the debate to answer some of the allegations made by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who accused my colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) of pursuing a vendetta against the Director of the Australian War Memorial. Without canvassing all the issues, because there are many to be considered, I simply say this: According to the report that has been provided to the Council, the Minister raised some six instances of concern which were based upon false information being provided to him by the Director. In all of those six instances the statements made by the Minister were found to be justified. I do not want to canvass that aspect any further other than to say that I think that in itself negates the assertion made by the honourable member for Farrer.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to draw the attention of all honourable members to one other matter and that is the finding that an answer provided by the Minister to a member of the House contained false information. Clearly it was deliberately false and known to be false. One of the most important aspects, indeed the only aspect upon which the Westminster system can operate, is that all honourable members are expected under all circumstances never ever deliberately to mislead the House. Where that occurs there are ample findings to suggest that that is a contempt, and has to be treated as a contempt, by any honourable member who engages in that practice. There are adequate precedents to show that the only honourable course a Minister who deliberately misleads the House or lies to the House must follow is to submit his resignation. That is a standard that has been--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not many on your side.

—I am trying to make a serious point because I think it is time that all members of this House were prepared to assert the prerogatives of this Parliament over the prerogatives of the bureaucracy, irrespective of who is in government. If a member on the other side in the course of his parliamentary duties addresses a question, particularly a question on notice to a Minister, the Minister is entitled to see that all of the resources of his Department are brought to bear so that that information is answered as accurately and as honestly as possible.
—And as quickly.

—I agree with that. If in fact any public servant or any person holding a position of trust in respect of a Minister is possessed of information which is relevant to this House and to the member asking a question, knowingly, deliberately and dishonestly provides misinformation knowing that it is untrue, in my view, that also constitutes a gross contempt of this House. In my view, just as a Minister is called upon to account should he mislead the Parliament or any member of it, so too should anybody else.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in a very odd situation. It has been suggested by the honourable member for Farrer-I know he has too much regard for the parliamentary institution to assert it seriously-that because of a level of political support that he might want to give for other reasons to a director of the war museum, he would be prepared to say: `Well, we will overlook it this time'. I want to go on the public record as saying that, so long as I am a Minister, if any public servant provides misinformation, knowing that it is false, as far as I am concerned, that public servant ought to be dismissed. Unless a Minister insists on that standard, the whole Westminster system falls into disrepute.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are calling for his dismissal?

—No, that is a matter for the Council; it is a matter for the Minister who is directly responsible. I am asserting what my own position is. However, I believe it is an assertion which ought to command the support of every member of this House who believes, as I believe, in the efficacy and the integrity of the Westminster system.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to answer briefly the questions raised by the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) because he is a member who has the respect of this House and is entitled to a rational and sensible reply. I was surprised at his outburst because it was not typical of the way he usually approaches such matters. He referred to the recent controversy over woodchipping in Tasmania. To give some background to this matter, the memorandum of understanding on Tasmanian woodchip exports establishes a process of consultation designed to promote the conservation and development of forests, ensuring that the industry operates efficiently while recognising proper environmental concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: On 21 October this year the Australian Heritage Commission announced its decision to list Jackeys Marsh and Quamby Bluff on the National Estate Register. That decision triggered consideration of how National Estate values will be taken into account by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission. That point was acknowledged by Mr Gray himself in his telex to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 7 November, in which he referred to steps taken by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission under clause 27-namely, that the Forestry Commission has sought further advice on Register values. The fact is that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission did not seek that information until logging had recommenced in Jackeys Marsh. The Tasmanian Government has therefore authorised logging, and the possible destruction of National Estate values, before the process of discussion on how these values might be protected has had a chance to run its course. The Tasmanian Government's action is pre-emptive and highly provocative, and shows a blatant disregard for the environment.

It is important to remember that the memorandum of understanding is an agreement reached between the two governments to develop a process of consultation so that logging can proceed in Tasmania while at the same time National Estate values are preserved. The National Estate values identified by the Heritage Commission include the diversity of plant communities, rare and threatened plant species, areas of outstanding aesthetic value, archaeological sites and rainforests.

It is important, particularly in these early stages when we are developing this memorandum of understanding, when we are trying to work with the Tasmanian Government, the Tasmanian Forestry Commission and the Department of Primary Industry, including my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), that we make sure that all the processes are gone through fairly carefully. The Prime Minister has now called upon the Premier to stop logging in the area until the process of consultation has been allowed to run its full course. A Commonwealth Advisory Committee on Tasmanian Forestry Operations has been appointed and it is due to report on Jackeys Marsh within three weeks. The Heritage Commission is expected to complete its detailed work on National Estate values within two weeks. We are asking Mr Gray to cease logging in the area while the process of consultation and dispute settlement outlined in the memorandum of understanding runs its course. We are asking him, particularly in these very early stages of negotiation, with this memorandum of understanding being a very new document, to make sure that we go through all the due processes before logging proceeds. That is all we are saying. I really think that the honourable member for Lyons and the Premier have gone off a little half-cocked and have not given this Government credit for trying to make this memorandum of understanding work.
